content_it:
L’amministrazione comunale di Leskovac ha stanziato circa 13 milioni di dinari (oltre 111.000 euro) per la fornitura e l’installazione di 23 contenitori seminterrati per i rifiuti. Le ubicazioni precise saranno definite in una fase successiva, durante la preparazione della documentazione per la messa in esercizio.

Secondo quanto indicato nel bando di gara, si tratta di contenitori da tre metri cubi in polietilene, con una profondità massima di 1,5 metri. La parte fuori terra dovrà essere accessibile alle persone con disabilità, mentre il materiale dovrà essere impermeabile e privo di perdite. I contenitori devono inoltre resistere a urti, pressione del terreno, raggi UV e corrosione, occupando al massimo 1,35 metri quadrati di suolo pubblico. È richiesta anche la mobilità dell’unità, affinché possa essere spostata senza danneggiamenti.

La garanzia prevista è di dieci anni per la struttura e di due anni per il sacco interno e il coperchio. L’installazione comprende tra l’altro la realizzazione di una recinzione temporanea, la rimozione di asfalto e calcestruzzo, la preparazione e segnalazione dell’area, lo scavo, il posizionamento di bordure in cemento bianco e la posa di lastre in calcestruzzo.

L’aggiudicazione della fornitura sarà resa nota dopo il 15 ottobre, data di scadenza per la presentazione delle offerte.

Questa iniziativa potrebbe rappresentare un’opportunità per aziende italiane specializzate nella produzione di contenitori per rifiuti e servizi connessi all’igiene urbana.
title_it: Leskovac investe in contenitori seminterrati

title_en: Mali: 121 countries confirm participation in EXPO 2027, delay in construction of National Stadium to be compensated by working 20 hours a day
content_en: (Photo: Instagram/expo_belgrade_2027) Finance Minister Sinisa Mali stated that, up till then, 121 countries had confirmed participation in the specialized international exhibition “EXPO 2027” in Belgrade, which, as he stated, makes Serbia the most successful country in terms of the number of participants in specialized exhibitions. title_en: Changes being made to route of second line of Belgrade Subway – New stations at Slavija and near Karadjordje Park
content_en: (Photo: Nacrt plana generalne regulacije šinskih sistema u Beogradu sa elementima detaljne razrade druge linije metro sistema II etapa) The Secretariat for Urban Planning and Construction has made available for public inspection the Draft General Regulation Plan of the Rail Systems in Belgrade with elements of a detailed development of the second line of the metro system - Stage II. The biggest changes compared to the previous plan relate to changes to the route and the introduction of two new stations - Slavija (instead of Manjez) and the Karadjordje Park . The subject of the Plan is the detailed development of the second stage of the second line of the subway system and the amendment to the rules for the regulation and construction of the general part of the GRP of the rail systems, and related to the second subway line, whose route from the planned subway station Block 18 to the planned subway station Juzni Boulevard has been adjusted in relation to the solution defined by the GRP of the rail systems . The Plan boundary includes the area of detailed development of the second stage of the second line of the subway system, i.e. the area from the planned Mercator subway station to the planned Mirijevo subway station, along the route - Zorana Djindjica Boulevard, Block 18, Kraljice Drage Obrenovic Street, Devojacki park, Kralja Milana Street, Oslobodjenja Boulevard, Juzni Boulevard, Gospodara Vucica Boulevard, Kralja Aleksandra Boulevard and further through Mirijevo to the planned unified subway station of the first and second lines of the Mirijevo subway system, as well as the abandoned route of the second subway line from the planned Block 18 subway station to the planned Juzni Boulevard subway station. The Plan boundary also includes the area east of the Pancevo Bridge, between the Danube coastal belt, the planned access road to the bridge and the planned sewage collector, as well as the area in the Ada Huja zone, north of Visnjicka Street, south, southwest and west of the Kartonka Avala factory. The area covered by the Plan is approximately 208 ha. Changes in stations Subway Line 2 route, new plan : Bezanija Depot-Marka Celebonovica Street-KBC Bezanijska kosa-Zemun Rail Station-Zemun Novi grad-Ugrinovacka Street-Filipa Visnjica Street-Zemun Stadium-City Park-Dzona Kenedija Street-New Belgrade Municipality-Mercator-Arena-Block 18-Sava Square-Slavija-Karadjordje Park-Juzni Boulevard-Grcica Milenka Street-Vojislava Ilica Street-Zvezdara Market-Mite Ruzica Street-Ustanicka Street-Mirijevo. Subway Line 2 route, 2023 plan : Bezanija Depot-Marka Celebonovica Street-KBC Bezanijska kosa-Zemun Rail Station-Zemun Novi grad-Ugrinovacka Street-Filipa Visnjica Street-Zemun Stadium-City Park-Dzona Kenedija Street-New Belgrade Municipality-Mercator-Arena-Sava Centar-Block 18-Sava Square-Manjez-Makenzijeva Street-Juzni Boulevard-Grcica Milenka Street-Vojislava Ilica Street-Zvezdara Market-Mite Ruzica Street-Ustanicka Street-Mirijevo. So, according to the previous solution that was on public display in 2023, the route of the second line included the Manjez and Makenzijeva Street stations . Instead, the new plan envisages a station on the Slavija Square, the construction of which also includes the Miticeva rupa zone, as well as the Karadjordje Park station, in the immediate vicinity of the rail station of the same name and at the entrance to the rail tunnel. (Photo: Nacrt plana generalne regulacije šinskih sistema u Beogradu sa elementima detaljne razrade druge linije metro sistema II etapa) The Karadjordje Park station will, as stated, be one of the key transfer hubs in the city, as it will enable the connection of the subway with tram and bus lines, as well as with the urban-suburban railway (Beovoz) stop. This, as stated in the plan, will achieve a high level of intermodality of the public transport system in Belgrade. Incidentally, according to the draft of the GRP of the rail systems in Belgrade with elements of a detailed development of the second line of the subway system, which was on public display in 2023 , the route of the second section has been changed in the part that passes through the Bezanijska kosa settlement, and it is now planned that the line will “turn” through the Bezanijska kosa settlement and include the Bezanijska kosa Clinical Hospital Center. Number of passengers According to data from the Preliminary Design of the first phase of line 1 and the Conceptual Solution of line 3, as well as based on additional modeling conducted by the French company EGIS after the correction of the line 2 route, the highest load within the planned subway system is expected on line one . On the section from the Danube station to the Pancevo Bridge, around 10,670 passengers are expected to travel during the morning peak hour in the direction of Karaburma, while on the section from Ada Ciganlija to the Sava Square, the number of passengers will exceed 9,000 during the same period. The two busiest sections on the line will be between Block 18 and the Sava Square stations with more than 8,000 passengers during the morning peak hour. For the third line , a total of around 24,600 passengers are estimated during the morning peak hour, and on the busiest section around 6,100 passengers per direction. Public access to the plan will last until October 22. The preparation of the documentation has been entrusted to the Belgrade Urban Planning Institute, while the contracting authority is the Belgrade Metro and Train Public Utility Company. I. Z. Il Segretariato per l’Urbanistica e le Costruzioni di Belgrado ha reso pubblico il progetto del Piano Generale di Regolamentazione dei Sistemi Ferroviari della capitale, comprendente lo sviluppo dettagliato della seconda linea della metropolitana – Fase II. Le principali modifiche rispetto al piano precedente riguardano il tracciato e l’introduzione di due nuove stazioni: Slavija (al posto di Manjež) e Karadjordje Park.

L’area oggetto del piano copre circa 208 ettari e include il percorso tra le stazioni Mercator e Mirijevo, attraverso i principali assi viari di Belgrado, nonché il tratto abbandonato tra Block 18 e Južni Boulevard. Il nuovo tracciato prevede ora una fermata nella piazza Slavija, con interventi anche nell’area di “Miticeva rupa”, e una stazione a Karadjordje Park, in prossimità dell’omonima stazione ferroviaria e dell’imbocco della galleria ferroviaria.

La stazione Karadjordje Park diventerà un importante nodo di interscambio, collegando la metropolitana con tram, autobus e il servizio ferroviario urbano-suburbano (Beovoz), elevando così il livello di intermodalità del trasporto pubblico cittadino. Inoltre, il tracciato è stato modificato anche nel quartiere di Bežanijska kosa per includere il Centro Clinico Ospedaliero di Bežanijska kosa.

Secondo le stime aggiornate dalla società francese EGIS, la linea 1 rimarrà la più trafficata: si prevedono circa 10.670 passeggeri nell’ora di punta mattutina tra Danubio e il Ponte di Pančevo, e oltre 9.000 tra Ada Ciganlija e Piazza Sava. Sulla linea 2, i tratti più affollati saranno tra Block 18 e Piazza Sava, con oltre 8.000 passeggeri. Per la linea 3, il carico massimo è stimato in 6.100 passeggeri per senso di marcia sul tratto più trafficato.

La consultazione pubblica del piano resterà aperta fino al 22 ottobre. La documentazione è stata elaborata dall’Istituto Urbanistico di Belgrado, su incarico della società pubblica “Belgrade Metro and Train”.

Queste importanti infrastrutture offrono opportunità per imprese italiane specializzate in costruzioni, ingegneria civile, impiantistica e fornitura di materiali per grandi opere di trasporto urbano.

title_en: Crossing the Atlantic – athlete and climate advocate Michael Walther paddling from Europe to South America
content_en: Michael Walther paddles up to 15 hours a day in order to reach his destination by December (Photo: Fil Šrajer/Gebruder Weiss) Michael Walther is currently crossing the Atlantic Ocean on a stand-up paddleboard (SUP). The transatlantic paddleboard journey highlights marine conservation, with Gebrüder Weiss providing logistics and communications support. This Saturday, extreme athlete and climate advocate Michael Walther from Kiel, Germany, set off from Lagos, Portugal, making an attempt to set a new world record and cross the Atlantic Ocean on a stand-up paddleboard (SUP). His journey will span approximately 6,000 kilometers (3,700 miles), taking him past the Canary Islands and Cape Verde before reaching French Guiana. Walther is undertaking this challenge solo and without a support vessel. His mission is to draw attention to the threats facing the oceans due to climate change and to collect valuable scientific data for marine research. Before the journey could begin, logistics partner Gebrüder Weiss handled the transportation of the specially designed SUP board from Germany to Portugal. The company has been supporting Walther for several months and is also assisting with communications efforts to raise awareness of his mission. "With his transatlantic crossing, Michael Walther is sending an important signal for ocean conservation. We are proud to support him as a partner and wish him strength and perseverance on his journey," says Robert Stahlschmidt, Country Manager Air & Sea Germany at Gebrüder Weiss . Once the crossing is complete, Gebrüder Weiss will return the paddleboard to Germany via climate-neutral sea freight. The company uses a certified insetting approach, which reduces CO2 emissions directly within the transport chain by utilizing sustainable fuels rather than offsetting emissions through external projects. More information about Gebrüder Weiss ’s sustainability efforts can be found at: 👉https://www.gw-world.com/company/sustainability/future-of-mobility and on the company's social media channels. Since 2021, Gebrüder Weiss has been actively supporting innovation projects in sustainable transportation, collaborating with universities, research institutions, and startups. Fact Box – Atlantic Crossing by SUP • Route: From Portugal via the Canary Islands and Cape Verde to French Guiana • Distance: Approx. 6,000 kilometers (3,728 miles), around 4 million paddle strokes • SUP Board: Modeled after offshore rowing boats, includes a 2 m² sleeping cabin in the bow • Equipment: 200 kg of (440 lbs) food, life raft, medical kit, tools • Navigation: GPS, chart plotter, satellite phone, radio • Research: Hydrophone for recording marine animal sounds • Live Tracking: https://zeroemissions.eu/live Gebruder Weiss d.o.o. title_en: Plans to bring back trams to Nis and establish new rail route through Pantelej
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Orhan Cam/shutterstock.com) Reconstructing the existing rail line that runs through Nis and using it for trams, as well as creating a new railroad “circular ring” that would serve as public transport - these are some of the ideas included in the Urban Mobility Plan presented today in Nis. According to city councilor Igor Grmusa, the old rail corridor creates the possibility of a new form of public transport. He emphasizes that these are plans for the future and that they will be possible only after the construction of the rail bypass is completed. – The plan is to introduce public rail traffic to Pantelej in the future, or to create a ring from the Rail Station, Niska Banja, Trosarina, or Stop Shop, then Lion 3, then along the new boulevard to Heroja sa Kosara Boulevard and back to the rail station – says Grmusa. He explains that the old rail route can be used for public transport, but that it is necessary to lower the track to the level of the road and not make it look like a rampart. As he says, it would actually be used by trams. – That translates to trams. There is also an idea to introduce something like BG voz. It operates by renting rail cars and a locomotive from Srbija voz, and only the track from Serbian Railways – Grmusa explains. New boulevards, pedestrian and bicycle paths are also planned, but the councilor does not specify when any of the announced ones will be implemented, but that it is only a plan for the future. Incidentally, the option of returning trams to Nis has been mentioned for several years. For example, this item was included in the Development Program of the City of Nis for 2019. Trams in Nis began operating on November 16, 1930, and transported the people of Nis until August 10, 1958, when thousands of people gathered to see them off. content_it:
Il Piano per la Mobilità Urbana presentato oggi a Niš prevede il ripristino della linea ferroviaria esistente per l’utilizzo da parte di tram, nonché la creazione di un nuovo “anello circolare” ferroviario da impiegare come mezzo di trasporto pubblico. Secondo l’assessore comunale Igor Grmuša, il vecchio corridoio ferroviario offre l’opportunità di introdurre una nuova forma di mobilità collettiva, anche se la realizzazione è subordinata al completamento della variante ferroviaria. 

Il progetto prevede un percorso che colleghi la stazione ferroviaria con i quartieri di Niska Banja, Trosarina, Stop Shop, Lion 3, proseguendo lungo il nuovo viale fino al viale Heroja sa Kosara e ritorno alla stazione. Grmuša ha chiarito che la linea esistente potrebbe essere adattata al trasporto pubblico abbassando i binari al livello stradale, trasformandola di fatto in una linea tranviaria. È inoltre emersa l’ipotesi di un servizio simile al BG Voz, basato sul noleggio di carrozze e locomotive da Srbija Voz, utilizzando esclusivamente l’infrastruttura delle Ferrovie Serbe.

Il piano include anche la realizzazione di nuovi viali, percorsi pedonali e ciclabili, sebbene non siano state indicate tempistiche precise per l’attuazione. L’ipotesi del ritorno dei tram a Niš circola da diversi anni ed era già presente nel programma di sviluppo comunale del 2019. I tram avevano operato nella città dal 16 novembre 1930 al 10 agosto 1958, quando furono definitivamente ritirati dopo un lungo servizio.

title_en: Floors found under building of abolished Main Rail Station to be turned into depot of Historical Museum of Serbia
content_en: Former Main Rail Station in Belgrade (Photo: Dejan Aleksić) Two underground floors found during the adaptation of the building of the abolished Main Rail Station in Belgrade, which will house the Historical Museum of Serbia, will be its depot, it was said yesterday during a visit to the construction site by the ministers of finance and culture, Sinisa Mali and Nikola Selakovic. Mali said that new archaeology, natural history and Nikola Tesla museums would be built in Belgrade, and that the buildings of the Belgrade City Museum and the Aeronautical Museum would be reconstructed, Beta reported. These projects are part of the “Leap into the Future - Serbia 2027” program, which includes 323 projects in Serbia with the aim of being completed by the start of the world specialized exhibition EXPO 2027 in Surcin near Belgrade. The Minister of Culture said that the future building of the Historical Museum of Serbia would also become an educational center on the history of its statehood. There will be exhibitions “from the prehistory of the Serbs, through the pre-statehood period, the Nemanjic era, the era of the Serbian kingdom, empire and despotate. The period up to the First World War will be covered, and the idea is to create an exhibition for the 20th century as well,” said Selakovic. Director of the Historical Museum Dusica Bojic said she was glad that “someone remembered that after 63 years the Historical Museum should get its own building.” Fotografije: +1 Istorijski muzej Srbije Ministarstvo finansija Republike Srbije Ministarstvo kulture Republike Srbije old Main Rail Station Belgrade Historical Museum of Serbia Siniša Mali Nikola Selaković Dušica Bojić Leap into the Future Serbia 2027 Your comment Send
content_it: Durante i lavori di adattamento dell’ex stazione ferroviaria centrale di Belgrado, destinata a ospitare il Museo Storico della Serbia, sono stati scoperti due piani interrati che saranno adibiti a deposito del museo. Lo hanno annunciato ieri i ministri delle Finanze e della Cultura, Siniša Mali e Nikola Selaković, in occasione di una visita al cantiere. Mali ha confermato che a Belgrado sorgeranno nuovi musei dedicati all’archeologia, alla storia naturale e a Nikola Tesla, e che saranno ristrutturati gli edifici del Museo della Città di Belgrado e del Museo Aeronautico. Questi interventi rientrano nel programma “Balzo nel Futuro – Serbia 2027”, che comprende 323 progetti in tutto il Paese con l’obiettivo di completarli entro l’avvio dell’Esposizione mondiale specializzata EXPO 2027 a Surčin, nei pressi di Belgrado. Il ministro Selaković ha sottolineato che la futura sede del Museo Storico diverrà anche un centro educativo sulla storia dello Stato serbo, con esposizioni che spazieranno dalla preistoria dei Serbi fino al periodo successivo alla Prima guerra mondiale, incluso un percorso dedicato al XX secolo. La direttrice del Museo Storico, Dušica Bojić, ha espresso soddisfazione per il fatto che, dopo 63 anni, l’istituzione avrà finalmente una sede propria. Per le imprese italiane specializzate in restauro architettonico e allestimenti museali, questi progetti rappresentano opportunità concrete di collaborazione in un contesto di rinnovamento culturale strategico.
title_it: Deposito museale sotto ex stazione ferroviaria

title_en: Initiative to modernize railroad between Trieste and Belgrade being considered
content_en: (Photo: Vivvi Smak/shutterstock) The Central European Initiative (CEI) meeting, which will be held on the sidelines of the 80th session of the United Nations General Assembly, is of exceptional importance, as it will consider the initiative to modernize rail traffic between Trieste and Belgrade and the rail border crossing between Serbia and Croatia, announced the President of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Serbia (CCIS), Marko Cadez. Cadez, who is in New York as a member of the Serbian delegation, reminded that the initiative to modernize that rail corridor had been launched by the CCIS and the Croatian Chamber of Economy. According to him, the Adriatic-Ionian Initiative has also joined the idea, which speaks to the importance of the undertaking for all countries in the region, from Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, to Serbia. – We will try to revive this route and accelerate the dynamics, because it is important for all of us. The economies of Serbia, Croatia, Slovenia, and Italy live from it – said Cadez. He pointed out that a large part of Serbian exports, but also imports, went through the ports of Rijeka and Kopar, which were on that route. – Therefore, the meeting is a good opportunity to talk again with representatives of all the countries that are taking this initiative and to emphasize the need for this project – said Cadez. The President of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Serbia also announced that he would invite the CEI member states to visit the upcoming “Wine Vision” fair, so that a meeting on the topic of modernizing the Belgrade-Trieste rail transport could be held within the framework of that event. content_it:
L’iniziativa per la modernizzazione del traffico ferroviario tra Trieste e Belgrado, nonché del valico ferroviario di confine tra Serbia e Croazia, sarà all’ordine del giorno di un incontro della Iniziativa Centro Europea (ICE) a margine dell’80ª sessione dell’Assemblea Generale delle Nazioni Unite. Lo ha annunciato il presidente della Camera di Commercio e Industria della Serbia (CCIS), Marko Čadež, attualmente a New York come membro della delegazione serba.  

Čadež ha ricordato che l’iniziativa per la modernizzazione di questo corridoio ferroviario era stata lanciata congiuntamente dalla CCIS e dalla Camera di Economia croata, e che successivamente si è unita anche l’Iniziativa Adriatico-Ionica, a conferma dell’importanza strategica del progetto per tutta la regione – dall’Italia alla Slovenia, dalla Croazia alla Serbia.  

«Cercheremo di rilanciare questa rotta e accelerarne l’attuazione, poiché è fondamentale per tutti noi. Le economie di Serbia, Croazia, Slovenia e Italia ne traggono vantaggio diretto», ha affermato Čadež, sottolineando che una parte significativa delle esportazioni e importazioni serbe transita attraverso i porti di Rijeka e Capodistria, situati lungo questo itinerario.  

Il presidente della CCIS ha inoltre annunciato l’intenzione di invitare gli Stati membri dell’ICE a partecipare alla prossima fiera “Wine Vision”, dove potrebbe tenersi un incontro dedicato proprio alla modernizzazione del collegamento ferroviario Belgrado-Trieste.  

L’attuazione di questo progetto rappresenterebbe un’importante opportunità per le imprese italiane attive nei settori delle infrastrutture ferroviarie, della logistica e della subfornitura industriale.

title_en: Tender for revitalization of medieval town of Maglic announced
content_en: Maglic Fortress (Photo: Shutterstock/trabantos) The Institute for the Protection of Cultural Monuments Kraljevo has announced a tender for the implementation of works on the revitalization of the medieval town of Maglic, as part of the sixth phase of emergency interventions and technical maintenance. The estimated value of the works is 3,185,500 dinars. The works include the repair of serious damage to the walls between towers I and VII, VII and VIII, the connection of the donjon tower with the eastern wall, as well as on the southern corner of tower VI, where stone has fallen out of the wall. Special attention will also be paid to cleaning the interior of the donjon tower and the northern wall from weeds, brushwood, trees and garbage, with treatment with chemical agents against weeds. The installation of missing thresholds, pillar supports and fences made of industrially impregnated oak and acacia wood is planned, with the application of protective antifungal and anti-insecticidal coatings. In places where the wall mass has fallen out, sealing will be carried out, and the missing parts of the walls will be built using a technique identical to the original wall. Also, a new footpath made of oak wood will be built between towers I and II on the eastern rampart. The contractor is obliged to provide all necessary equipment and materials, as well as auxiliary workers and transport. The works are supervised by an expert from the Institute for the Protection of Cultural Monuments in Kraljevo. Access to the location is difficult because the high bridge over the Ibar River that led to the fortification was washed away by a torrent of water, which further complicates the execution of the works. The warranty periods begin to run from the date of mutual signing of the records on the handover of the works. The deadline for submitting bids is October 8, and more details can be found HERE . Fotografije: +4 Opis: Maglič je srednjovekovni zamak u ibarskoj klisuri, 20 km južno od Kraljeva. Smešten je na vrhu brda, oko koga Ibar pravi oštru okuku čime podnožje brda okružuje sa tri strane. Zaravnjeni plato na kom je utvrđenje podignuto uzdiže se nekih stotinak metara od dna klisure i jedinog karavanskog puta koji je povezivao Moravsku dolinu i Kosovo polje. Sredinom 2006. godine je tvrđava privremeno bila zatvorena za posetioce zbog istrunulosti drvenih platformi u kulama koje bi mogle popustiti pod čovečijom težinom, a sama tvrđava je noću osvetljenja, čime privlači dodatnu pažnju prolaznika magistralnog puta. Početkom jeseni 2010. godine, najavljeno je da će Italija u saradnji sa gradom Kraljevom finansirati obnovu Magliča. Ovo je realizovano i avgusta 2013. je otvoren Ekomuzej. Maglič čini 8 kula povezanih bedemima, a u njegovu unutrašnjost, koja obuhvata 2.190 m2, ulazi se kroz dve kapije. On ima izduženu osnovu i prostire se pravcem jugozapad-severoistok. Sa tri strane brdo na kome se utvrđenje nalazi okružuje Ibar, dok se na četvrtoj strani tj. krajnjem severoistočnom kraju nalazi šanac usečen u stenu. Iznad šanca se uzdiže 1. kula (Donžon) sa tzv. malim gradom, dok je kamen izvađen iz šanca ugrađen u tvrđavu. Na suprotnom, jugozapadnom, kraju smeštene su jedna uz drugu tri kule (6, 7. i 8.) koje su kontrolisale prilaz niz Ibar, čije je korito nekoliko kilometara pre Magliča gotovo pravolinijsko, tako da se te tri kule uočavaju sa velike udaljenosti. U Maglič se ulazi kroz kapiju (I) smeštenu na severnom bedemu između 1. i 2. kule, dok se drugi ulaz (II) tj. izlaz nalazi nasuprot nje u 3. kuli. Unutar utvrđenja izgrađeno je nekoliko građevina smeštenih celom dužinom zapadnog bedema, kao i dve (1 + 1 u malom gradu) cisterne, izdubljene u steni. content_it:
L’Istituto per la Protezione dei Monumenti Culturali di Kraljevo ha indetto una gara per i lavori di revitalizzazione del castello medievale di Maglič, nell’ambito della sesta fase di interventi d’emergenza e manutenzione tecnica. Il valore stimato dell’appalto è di 3.185.500 dinari.

Gli interventi prevedono la riparazione di gravi danni alle mura tra le torri I e VII, VII e VIII, il collegamento della torre mastio con il muro orientale e il consolidamento dell’angolo meridionale della torre VI, dove sono cadute parti in pietra. Sarà inoltre effettuata la pulizia dell’interno della torre mastio e del muro settentrionale da erbacce, arbusti, alberi e rifiuti, con trattamento chimico antinfestante.

Sono previsti anche l’installazione di soglie mancanti, supporti per pilastri e recinzioni in legno di quercia e acacia industrialmente impregnato, trattato con prodotti protettivi antifungini e antitarlo. Nei punti in cui la muratura si è sgretolata, verrà eseguito il sigillo e le porzioni mancanti saranno ricostruite con la stessa tecnica originaria. Inoltre, sarà realizzato un nuovo camminamento in legno di quercia tra le torri I e II sul bastione orientale.

L’appaltatore dovrà fornire tutta l’attrezzatura, i materiali, la manodopera ausiliaria e il trasporto necessari. I lavori saranno sorvegliati da un esperto dell’Istituto per la Protezione dei Monumenti Culturali di Kraljevo.

L’accesso al sito è difficoltoso poiché il ponte alto sul fiume Ibar, che conduceva alla fortezza, è stato distrutto da una piena. Il termine per la presentazione delle offerte è fissato all’8 ottobre.

Il castello di Maglič, situato nella gola dell’Ibar a circa 20 km a sud di Kraljevo, è un complesso fortificato composto da otto torri collegate da mura, con un’area interna di 2.190 m². Nel 2013, grazie a un finanziamento congiunto tra Italia e città di Kraljevo, è stato inaugurato l’Ecomuseo.

Per le imprese italiane specializzate nel restauro monumentale, nei materiali per beni culturali e nelle lavorazioni lignee pregiate, questa gara rappresenta un’ulteriore occasione di collaborazione nel mercato serbo.
title_it: Gara per il restauro del castello di Maglič

title_en: Marina Dorcol sales pavilion – Innovative VR walk through most attractive investment in Belgrade
content_en: (Photo: Nenad Dimić) Today, a global innovation in the real estate industry was exclusively presented to the public - an experience of the future Marina Dorcol settlement in virtual reality (VR). By opening the Marina Dorcol sales pavilion in Belgrade, investor SEBRE introduced a new standard in the domestic real estate market. (Photo: Nenad Dimić) The pavilion offers buyers and investors the opportunity to experience the project before it is completed through a model, exhibition materials and a special VR experience in a cave, a virtual walk through the apartments and a panoramic view of the river. “Most often, people who buy apartments in Marina Dorcol decide to buy for their families. They have recognized the quality of construction, comfort and security that the project offers. At the same time, we also have buyers who know that a good view, location and quality construction never lose value, which is why they decide to make this investment,” said Miodrag Gazibara, Sales Director of Marina Dorcol. Buyer interest is already confirming the attractiveness of the project, with more than 40% of the apartments in the first phase having been sold, ranging from one-bedroom to luxury penthouse units. (Photo: Nenad Dimić) The first phase includes a total of 263 apartments, began in July of this year, and is scheduled for completion in the third quarter of 2028. Marina Dorcol was designed by world-renowned Czech architect Stanislav Fiala and Serbian architect Jelena Kuzmanovic within the partnership firm Kuzmanovic + Fiala. The project also offers numerous public facilities: a riverside promenade, shops and catering areas, pontoons for recreational water sports, and as much as 30,000 m² of green areas, along with special garages and comfortable parking spaces . (Photo: Nenad Dimić) The sales pavilion shows that Marina Dorcol is changing the way real estate is presented in Serbia, through a combination of architecture, innovation, and direct customer experience. Located at 43 Karadjordjeva Street, it is open to anyone who wants to get to know this project firsthand on site. You can see more about the Marina Dorcol sales pavilion in the promotional video https://we.tl/t-vszDCHeWKe Opis: Kompleks je spratnosti Su+P-Po+Pr+13, ukupne BRGP 195.853,35 m2, od čega nadzemno ukupne BRGP 139.624,54 m2. Kompleks Marina Dorćol imaće ukupno 564 stana, 39 lokala, 68 poslovnih apartmana, dva depadansa predškolskih ustanova i dva pomoćna objekta u funkciji tehničke infrastrukture, kao i 1.181 parking mestom u podzemnim garažama od čega je 62 parking mesta za osobe sa posebnim potrebama. A Belgrado è stato presentato al pubblico un innovativo padiglione vendite per il progetto immobiliare Marina Dorćol, che introduce un nuovo standard nel mercato serbo grazie all’uso della realtà virtuale (VR). L’iniziativa, promossa dall’investitore SEBRE, consente a potenziali acquirenti e investitori di esplorare in anticipo il complesso residenziale attraverso modelli, materiali espositivi e un’esperienza immersiva in VR: una passeggiata virtuale negli appartamenti e una vista panoramica sul fiume.

«La maggior parte degli acquirenti sceglie Marina Dorćol per le proprie famiglie, riconoscendone la qualità costruttiva, il comfort e la sicurezza. Altri investono convinti che vista, posizione e qualità non perdano mai valore», ha dichiarato Miodrag Gazibara, direttore commerciale del progetto. L’interesse è già tangibile: oltre il 40% degli alloggi della prima fase, che comprende 263 unità abitative – dagli monolocali alle lussuose attici – è già stato venduto. I lavori, avviati a luglio 2024, si concluderanno nel terzo trimestre del 2028.

Il progetto è frutto della collaborazione tra l’architetto ceco Stanislav Fiala e la serba Jelena Kuzmanović (studio Kuzmanović + Fiala) e prevede ampi spazi pubblici: una passeggiata lungofiume, aree commerciali e di ristorazione, pontili per sport acquatici e ben 30.000 m² di aree verdi, oltre a parcheggi sotterranei con 1.181 posti, di cui 62 riservati a persone con disabilità.

Il padiglione, situato al civico 43 di via Karađorđeva, rappresenta un cambiamento radicale nella presentazione immobiliare in Serbia, unendo architettura, innovazione e coinvolgimento diretto del cliente. Per le imprese italiane attive nel settore delle tecnologie immersive, dell’architettura o dei servizi immobiliari, questa evoluzione del mercato serbo potrebbe rappresentare un’interessante opportunità di collaborazione o esportazione di know-how.
title_it: Innovazione immobiliare a Belgrado con la realtà virtuale

title_en: Relocation of railroad necessary due to expansion of mining activities in Bor – New route with 3.5 km tunnel and bridge
content_en: (Photo: Saobraćajni institut CIP) The Serbian Railway Infrastructure company has submitted a request to the Ministry of Environmental Protection for a decision on the need for an environmental impact assessment of the phase-based construction and relocation of part of the rail line no. 218 Mala Krsna-Bor-Rasputnica 2 (Vrazogrnac), on the section through the Jama Bor zone. The request was prepared by the Institute of Transportation CIP. This is a section of the railroad from the km 216+577.77 point to the Bor-passenger station, with a total length of 4.62 kilometers. The relocation is necessary due to the continuation of copper ore exploitation in the Jama mine, as part of the plans of the Serbia ZiJin Copper company, but also due to the safety risks posed to the existing route by the old open-pit mine in Bor. Two tunnels are planned on the section. Tunnel T1, 561 m long (from km 216+937 to km 217+498), with accompanying evacuation plateaus and power units, and Tunnel T2, 3,569 m long (from km 217+601 to km 221+170), with a parallel evacuation tunnel 2,526 m long and a vertical evacuation exit. In addition to the tunnel, a new single-track rail bridge 29 m long has been designed, at km 217+563.33, with which the railroad will bridge the Valja Dosuli stream and the ravine. The bridge will be constructed as a three-span reinforced concrete structure. The planned speed on this section will be 80 km/h. I. Z. content_it: La società serba Infrastruttura Ferroviaria ha presentato al Ministero della Protezione Ambientale una richiesta per avviare la valutazione di impatto ambientale relativa alla costruzione graduale e alla deviazione di un tratto della linea ferroviaria n. 218 Mala Krsna–Bor–Rasputnica 2 (Vrazogrnac), nella zona di Jama Bor. La richiesta è stata redatta dall’Istituto dei Trasporti CIP. Il tratto interessato si estende dal chilometro 216+577,77 fino alla stazione passeggeri di Bor, per un totale di 4,62 chilometri. La deviazione si rende necessaria per proseguire l’estrazione di minerale di rame nella miniera di Jama, nell’ambito dei piani di Serbia ZiJin Copper, e per i rischi alla sicurezza derivanti dalla vecchia miniera a cielo aperto di Bor. Sono previsti due tunnel: il T1, lungo 561 metri (dal km 216+937 al km 217+498), completo di piazzole di evacuazione e impianti elettrici, e il T2, di 3.569 metri (dal km 217+601 al km 221+170), affiancato da un tunnel parallelo di evacuazione di 2.526 metri e da un’uscita verticale di emergenza. Inoltre, al km 217+563,33 è previsto un nuovo ponte ferroviario monobinario di 29 metri per attraversare il torrente Valja Dosuli e la vallata circostante, realizzato come struttura in cemento armato a tre campate. La velocità prevista su questo tratto sarà di 80 km/h. La realizzazione dell’opera apre opportunità per imprese italiane specializzate in infrastrutture ferroviarie, gallerie e costruzioni in cemento armato.

title_en: Invest in Montenegro – A Smart Choice for Bold Visions: We present eKapija's new special edition newsletter
content_en: (Photo: eKapija) The eKapija business portal has published the special edition newsletter Invest in Montenegro – A Smart Choice for Bold Visions . In this special edition, you can read about the key economic indicators that shape the investment climate in Montenegro. Through conversations with business leaders and decision-makers, we analyze the business environment and macroeconomic trends, showing how global and domestic developments affect the Montenegrin economy and its investment potential. Nina Drakic, President of the Chamber of Commerce of Montenegro , emphasizes that investors are only looking for clear "rules of the game," consistent application of regulations and an open dialogue between the state and the economy. Therefore, she says, it is important that Montenegro, in addition to reforms that will improve the business environment, devise and develop support mechanisms that will attract investors precisely to sectors with the greatest development potential. Arijana Nikolic Vucinic, Executive Director of the Foreign Investors Council of Montenegro , says in an interview with eKapija that, despite the slight increase in the ease of doing business index in 2024, Montenegro still faces numerous challenges that make it difficult to attract productive and long-term investments. Key challenges, such as the lack of transparency, frequent changes in legislation and low efficiency of public administration, continue to slow down the development of the business environment. In the Bijelo Polje industrial zone, on the site of the former Yugoslav giant Vunko, Bravera City Park, the largest retail center in Montenegro and the region, was recently opened. Behind this project is the Velickovic family, brothers Vladimir and Petar , who have been investing in their city for more than three decades. And they do not intend to stop, on the contrary. As they said in an interview with eKapija, a second phase of Bravera City Park development is planned, within which sports fields will also be built. And they also want to build a high-class hotel in one of the best locations in Bijelo Polje. Carine continues to push the boundaries of hotel offerings on the Montenegrin coast, announcing the construction of the largest hotel in the country and the region in Baosici. In parallel, the company is also developing a project in Kumbor and Djenovici, a mixed-use complex that will combine hotel capacities and residential units, including the option of a time-share model. We talked about all this with Vladimir Popovic, General Manager of Carine . On the coast of Risan, the oldest town in the heart of the Bay of Kotor, a unique project is being created - Movenpick Hotel & Residences Teuta Kotor Bay . The first resort of the renowned Swiss brand in Montenegro brings a new vision of life by the sea, combining top-notch hotel service and the authenticity of local heritage. In addition to the hotel, the project also includes fully equipped, branded residences for purchase, which provide owners with an exclusive lifestyle and the opportunity for smart investment. Lustica Bay is opening a new chapter in the development of The Peaks golf resort, with a collection of 11 three-bedroom townhouses overlooking the UNESCO-protected Bay of Kotor. Located next to the fifth hole of the future championship golf course, this edition of townhouses offers a higher level of privacy and represents an unbeatable option for living in a peaceful, natural environment. Terraforming has unveiled the Kalista Residence complex, which is being built in the very center of Kolasin, in a prestigious location on Milivoja Bulatovica Street. Kalista Residence is a modern residential and business complex that brings a new standard of living and investment. Every detail of the complex is designed to meet the highest standards of modern construction. Velje Brdo , the largest residential project in Montenegro, plans to offer the first apartments by 2026 at a price of 1,000 euros per square meter, with favorable repayment terms over 30 years and an interest rate of 1.2%. More than 10,000 citizens have expressed interest, which confirms that there is a huge demand for this model of housing construction. In the new issue, find out how Montenegro can harness the potential of the blue economy , whether it is possible to buy real estate in Montenegro with cryptocurrencies , and how it can become a global destination for digital nomads . content_it:
Il portale business eKapija ha pubblicato un’edizione speciale dedicata agli investimenti in Montenegro, dal titolo “Investire in Montenegro – Una scelta intelligente per visioni ambiziose”. Il documento analizza gli indicatori economici chiave che influenzano il clima d’investimento nel Paese, esaminando tendenze macroeconomiche e il contesto imprenditoriale attraverso interviste con leader del settore e decisori istituzionali.

Nina Drakić, presidente della Camera di Commercio del Montenegro, sottolinea come gli investitori cerchino regole chiare, applicazione coerente della normativa e un dialogo aperto tra istituzioni ed economia. Secondo la Drakić, è fondamentale che, oltre alle riforme per migliorare il contesto imprenditoriale, il Montenegro sviluppi meccanismi di sostegno mirati ai settori con il maggior potenziale di sviluppo.

Arijana Nikolić Vučinić, direttrice esecutiva del Consiglio degli Investitori Esteri del Montenegro, rileva che nonostante un lieve miglioramento dell’indice “ease of doing business” nel 2024, il Paese affronta tuttora sfide significative – tra cui scarsa trasparenza, continui cambiamenti normativi e inefficienza della pubblica amministrazione – che ostacolano investimenti produttivi e di lungo termine.

Nell’area industriale di Bijelo Polje, sul sito dell’ex gigante jugoslavo Vunko, è stato recentemente inaugurato il Bravera City Park, il più grande centro commerciale del Montenegro e della regione. Il progetto è promosso dai fratelli Vladimir e Petar Veličković, investitori attivi nella città da oltre trent’anni. È già prevista una seconda fase di sviluppo, che includerà campi sportivi e la costruzione di un hotel di alto livello in una delle posizioni migliori della città.

Sulla costa, la società Carine sta ampliando la propria offerta alberghiera con la costruzione del più grande hotel del Paese a Baosici, oltre a un complesso residenziale e alberghiero a Kumbor e Đenovići, che prevede anche la formula del time-share. Il progetto è stato illustrato da Vladimir Popović, amministratore delegato di Carine.

A Risan, la più antica città della Baia di Kotor, è in corso la realizzazione del Movenpick Hotel & Residences Teuta Kotor Bay, primo resort del rinomato brand svizzero in Montenegro. Il progetto unisce servizi alberghieri di alto livello con l’autenticità del patrimonio locale e offre residenze branded completamente arredate, pensate sia per uno stile di vita esclusivo che per investimenti strategici.

Luštica Bay ha avviato una nuova fase nello sviluppo del resort golfistico The Peaks, con 11 townhouse da tre camere affacciate sulla Baia di Kotor, sito UNESCO. Situate accanto al quinto green del futuro campo da golf di livello internazionale, queste abitazioni garantiscono privacy e comfort in un ambiente naturale incontaminato.

Nel centro di Kolašin, in una prestigiosa posizione su Milivoja Bulatovića, è in costruzione il complesso residenziale e direzionale Kalista Residence, sviluppato da Terraforming. Il progetto si propone di elevare gli standard abitativi e di investimento nella regione, con soluzioni costruttive all’avanguardia.

Infine, Velje Brdo, il più grande progetto residenziale del Montenegro, prevede la consegna dei primi appartamenti entro il 2026 al prezzo di 1.000 euro al metro quadrato, con piani di pagamento agevolati (30 anni, tasso d’interesse dell’1,2%). Oltre 10.000 cittadini hanno già manifestato interesse, segnale di una forte domanda per questo modello abitativo.

L’edizione speciale esplora inoltre il potenziale dell’economia blu, la possibilità di acquistare immobili con criptovalute e le opportunità per trasformare il Montenegro in una destinazione globale per i nomadi digitali.

Per le aziende italiane attive nei settori dell’edilizia, dell’ospitalità, delle energie rinnovabili e dei servizi digitali, il Montenegro rappresenta un mercato emergente con ampi margini di crescita e opportunità di investimento in progetti innovativi e sostenibili.
title_it: Investire in Montenegro: opportunità e sfide

title_en: First town houses next to the golf course with a view of Boka Kotorska - Luštica Bay's new residential collection
content_en: (Photo: Luštica Bay) Luštica Bay opens a new chapter in the development of The Peaks golf resort, with a collection of 11 three-bedroom townhouses overlooking the UNESCO-protected Boka Kotorska Bay. Located next to the fifth hole of a future championship golf course, this edition of townhouses offers a higher level of privacy and is an unbeatable option for living in a peaceful, natural setting. Gary Player, world-renowned golfer and designer of the golf course in Luštica Bay, said during his first swing at the practice area: "If I were to choose a home next to the golf course, I would choose Luštica Bay without a doubt." His words confirm the unique atmosphere, quality and special character of The Peaks once again. (Photo: Luštica Bay) The Peaks – the first golf resort in Montenegro The Peaks represents the crown of the development of a new city on the coast where architectural excellence and the unobtrusive elegance of a carefully selected location are strung together like two jewels. Added value is brought by the pronounced investment potential, since the settlement is developing around the only 18-hole golf course in Montenegro - the infrastructural, landscape and value backbone of this unique environment. Life at a height, overlooking one of the most beautiful bays in the world These two-story houses represent the first residential collection that offers a panoramic view of the Bay of Kotor and parts of the Gulf of Herceg Novi and Tivat, and the view reaches even to Perast and its two famous islands. With an area of 185 to 205 m², they offer clearly demarcated living and private zones, combining functionality with architectural refinement. Double-height ceilings in the living room, three bedrooms with their own bathrooms, an elegant fireplace, natural materials and spacious terraces of 70 - 87 m2 make these residences a real oasis of comfort. The green roof terraces, ranging in size from 45 to 83 m², further expand the living space and create a perfect corner for relaxation with a view of Boka. With spacious gardens ranging from 184 to 590 m² and plots that reach more than 1,000 m², these residences offer peace and privacy. (Photo: Luštica Bay) A flat green roof is represented in a large number of town houses, while the tradition is further accentuated with terracotta roofing - both versions are carefully integrated into the landscape and architectural context of the destination, emphasizing the balance between contemporary and authentic. Modern kitchens of renowned brands, underfloor heating in bathrooms, sophisticated air conditioning systems, as well as private and public parking spaces with the option of installing chargers for electric vehicles, guarantee the highest standard of modern living. In addition, future owners have the opportunity to choose between a basic and a more advanced package of built-in furniture, which leave enough space for individualizing the interior in accordance with different style preferences. This concept of living space calls for a Mediterranean way of life, which takes place outdoors for most of the year. The key advantage of town houses is reflected in the fact that the buyer practically enjoys the comfort of living in a villa, but at a more favorable price, with a minimum number of neighbors. The previous collection of townhouses represented an extremely attractive product within the Luštica Bay portfolio, with a very strong demand, which resulted in the townhouses finding their owners very quickly. (Photo: Luštica Bay) Box: Architecture inspired by landscape, heritage and sea views The internationally recognized studios Block 722 and the local NRA Atelier are responsible for the architecture of the complete golf resort, which created a superb architectural interpretation of the modern Mediterranean way of life in The Peaks. The architecture of the residences was inspired by the form of a traditional Luštica house, while NRA Atelier defined airy, light-filled interiors, with a seamless connection between interior and exterior framing the view of Boka Kotorska or the Adriatic. Luštica Bay – a growing city, a value that is being built The Peaks settlement is the most ambitious development settlement of Luštica Bay, a city on the coast that is being developed on a total area of ​​7 million m², with construction planned on only 10% of the territory, in accordance with a sustainable approach to development. This carefully thought-out balance between built and untouched nature represents the core value of the project. (Photo: Luštica Bay) Luštica Bay is already home to more than 700 families from 50 countries. With the already built Marina Village and Centrale neighborhoods as the city core, the contours of which are rapidly being completed, and more than 1,000 sold properties, Luštica Bay is growing into the largest integrated residential project in Montenegro, with a clear vision of development. It enjoys the reputation of a dynamic destination that nurtures the values ​​of a cosmopolitan community, with a rich spectrum of content - from cultural events, gastronomy in a number of restaurants, yachting services in the marina, to various events in sports and recreational areas. Upon completion, Luštica Bay will have more than 6,000 residents, more than 3,000 apartments, 300 villas and seven hotels. The completion of the golf course, seven beaches, a school and a health center will bring additional functional roundness, making it a first-class investment and living address on the Mediterranean. By 2033, it is estimated that the total investment will reach an impressive amount of EUR 1.6 billion, making Luštica Bay the largest greenfield investment in Montenegro and one of the largest in Southeast Europe. (Photo: Luštica Bay) Investment with increasing value and international attention The average annual growth in the value of real estate in Luštica Bay is 13% so far, while about 15% of the project has been completed. The golf course in Luštica Bay belongs to the elite 10% of world courses with sea views from every hole, which makes The Peaks extremely attractive for a global audience of investors, golf enthusiasts and buyers of luxury real estate. Right now, with the development of the golf area, the planned phased opening of the golf course and the limited number of townhouse units available, buyers are presented with a rare opportunity to enter a project with significant long-term growth potential. With growing international interest in this prestigious location, real estate in The Peaks is extremely well positioned to further increase in value within the most promising new destination on the Adriatic. (Photo: Luštica Bay) Special payment conditions for starting the sale of town houses The purchase is further facilitated by a special repayment plan, intended for early buyers on the occasion of the launch of this attractive zone of the golf resort. Payment structure starts with 20% down payment, continues with 50% in quarterly installments during the construction phase and ends with the remaining 30% in quarterly installments after handover, all without calculating interest. The townhouses are ready to move in or rent out immediately upon collection. Thanks to this flexible dynamic, buyers have the option to rent out the property even up to two years after handover, which enables the creation of additional income that can contribute to covering repayment and maintenance costs. This approach not only promotes the self-sustainability of the investment from the very beginning, but also contributes to the development of a community based on trust, a long-term relationship and a vision of life in a new coastal city. (Photo: Luštica Bay) Prices for this collection start at EUR 2.2 million. Luštica Bay inaugura una nuova fase dello sviluppo del resort golfistico The Peaks con una collezione di 11 townhouse trilocali affacciate sulla baia di Boka Kotorska, patrimonio UNESCO. Situate accanto al quinto buca del futuro campo da golf di livello internazionale, queste residenze offrono maggiore privacy e rappresentano un’opzione incomparabile per chi cerca una vita tranquilla immersa nella natura. Gary Player, leggendario golfista e progettista del campo, ha dichiarato: “Se dovessi scegliere una casa vicino a un campo da golf, sceglierei senza dubbio Luštica Bay”, confermando ulteriormente l’atmosfera unica e il valore distintivo di The Peaks.

Queste abitazioni su due piani, con superfici tra 185 e 205 m², regalano viste panoramiche sulla baia di Kotor, sul golfo di Castelnuovo (Herceg Novi) e Tivat, fino alle isole di Perasto. Gli interni combinano funzionalità e raffinatezza architettonica: soffitti a doppia altezza nel soggiorno, tre camere da letto con bagno privato, camino, materiali naturali e ampie terrazze da 70 a 87 m². A questi spazi si aggiungono tetti verdi di 45-83 m² e giardini privati da 184 a 590 m², su lotti che superano i 1.000 m², garantendo comfort, riservatezza e integrazione con il paesaggio.

L’architettura, curata dagli studi internazionali Block 722 e dallo studio locale NRA Atelier, si ispira alla casa tradizionale di Luštica e valorizza il rapporto fluido tra interni ed esterni. Le finiture includono cucine di brand prestigiosi, riscaldamento a pavimento, climatizzazione avanzata, parcheggi privati e pubblici con predisposizione per ricarica veicoli elettrici. Gli acquirenti possono scegliere tra diversi pacchetti di arredo, personalizzando gli interni secondo il proprio stile.

The Peaks si colloca all’interno del progetto più ambizioso di Luštica Bay, città costiera in costruzione su 7 milioni di m², con solo il 10% destinato a edificazione, nel rispetto di un approccio sostenibile. Già oggi vi risiedono oltre 700 famiglie provenienti da 50 Paesi, e sono state vendute più di 1.000 unità immobiliari. A completamento, il progetto prevede 6.000 abitanti, 3.000 appartamenti, 300 ville, sette hotel, un campo da golf, sette spiagge, una scuola e un centro sanitario. L’investimento complessivo raggiungerà 1,6 miliardi di euro entro il 2033, posizionando Luštica Bay come il più grande investimento greenfield del Montenegro e tra i maggiori del Sud-Est Europa.

Il valore immobiliare a Luštica Bay cresce in media del 13% annuo, nonostante solo il 15% del progetto sia completato. Il campo da golf, tra l’élite mondiale per la vista sul mare da ogni buca, accresce l’appeal internazionale del resort. Le nuove townhouse, disponibili in numero limitato, rappresentano un’opportunità rara per investire in una destinazione con solide prospettive di rivalutazione. Il piano di pagamento agevolato prevede un acconto del 20%, il 50% in rate trimestrali durante i lavori e il 30% dopo la consegna, senza interessi. Le unità sono subito abitabili o affittabili, con la possibilità di generare reddito già nei primi due anni, contribuendo a coprire i costi di rimborso e manutenzione. I prezzi partono da 2,2 milioni di euro.

Per le imprese italiane attive nel settore immobiliare di lusso, dell’interior design o dei servizi per l’ospitalità, Luštica Bay rappresenta un’opportunità strategica in un mercato in crescita con forte richiesta internazionale.
title_it: Nuove townhouse con vista golf a Luštica Bay

title_en: Velje Brdo, the largest urban project in the region - New city for 40,000 inhabitants, the first keys from 2026
content_en: (Photo: Printscreen) Velje Brdo, the largest housing project in Montenegro, plans to offer the first apartments by 2026 at a price of EUR 1,000 per square meter, with favorable repayment terms of 30 years and an interest rate of 1.2%. More than 10,000 citizens have expressed their interest, which confirms that there is a huge demand for this type of housing construction model. In August, the Government of Montenegro adopted the Spatial-Urban Plan of the Capital City of Podgorica, the main novelty of which is the new settlement Velje brdo. The project envisages the construction of up to 20,000 residential units, with an area of ​​60 and 100 square meters. On an area of ​​more than 900 hectares, about 4.5 million square meters of built-up areas are planned, intended for housing and business - residential buildings, slats and private houses. Within the complex, supporting facilities will be provided - schools, kindergartens, health institutions and business premises. (Photo: Printscreen) It will have about 57% of park areas, almost 500,000 square meters are planned for sports and recreation, while about 10 hectares will be under water surfaces The realization of this project, as previously announced, will proceed in phases, and an international competition for the selection of the best conceptual solution is expected. So far, tenders have been announced for the development of the conceptual solution and the main project, as well as for the revision of the main project of the Velje brdo boulevard with the accompanying infrastructure. In the long term, up to 40,000 inhabitants could live in Velje Brdo, which ranks it among the largest urban projects in the region. According to earlier announcements, construction is expected to begin at the end of 2025, while the first tenants should move in at the end of 2026 or the beginning of 2027. It remains to be seen how realistic this deadline is. At the same time, part of the professional public and associations point to the need for full transparency and protection of the area, since the location includes certain naturally sensitive areas. Velje Brdo, il più grande progetto residenziale del Montenegro, prevede di consegnare i primi appartamenti entro il 2026 a un prezzo di 1.000 euro al metro quadro, con condizioni di finanziamento particolarmente favorevoli: tasso d’interesse dell’1,2% e durata fino a 30 anni. Oltre 10.000 cittadini hanno già manifestato interesse, evidenziando una forte domanda per questo modello abitativo.

Nell’agosto scorso il governo montenegrino ha adottato il Piano Spaziale-Urbanistico della capitale Podgorica, introducendo come novità principale il nuovo insediamento di Velje Brdo. Il progetto prevede la costruzione di circa 20.000 unità abitative, con superfici di 60 e 100 metri quadrati, su un’area di oltre 900 ettari. Saranno realizzati complessivamente 4,5 milioni di metri quadrati di superficie edificabile, destinati a residenze, attività commerciali e uffici, oltre a villette e case unifamiliari.

L’area comprenderà servizi collettivi essenziali, tra cui scuole, asili, strutture sanitarie ed esercizi commerciali. Il 57% del territorio sarà destinato a parchi e aree verdi, quasi 500.000 metri quadrati saranno riservati a impianti sportivi e ricreativi, e circa 10 ettari saranno occupati da superfici d’acqua.

Il progetto sarà realizzato in fasi successive. È prevista una competizione internazionale per la selezione della migliore soluzione concettuale, dopo che sono già stati banditi appalti per lo sviluppo del progetto concettuale e del progetto definitivo, nonché per la revisione del progetto relativo al viale di Velje Brdo e alle relative infrastrutture.

A regime, Velje Brdo potrà ospitare fino a 40.000 abitanti, collocandosi tra i più ambiziosi interventi urbanistici della regione. Secondo le previsioni, i lavori cominceranno entro la fine del 2025, con i primi trasferimenti previsti per la fine del 2026 o l’inizio del 2027, sebbene la realizzabilità di tali tempistiche rimanga da verificare.

Alcuni esperti e associazioni sollevano tuttavia preoccupazioni sulla necessità di trasparenza e sulla protezione ambientale, poiché l’area interessata comprende zone naturali sensibili.  

Per le imprese italiane attive nel settore edile, delle infrastrutture e dei servizi tecnici, questa iniziativa rappresenta una potenziale opportunità di partecipazione a un progetto d’avanguardia di scala internazionale.

title_en: Bitcoin for an apartment by the sea - Is it possible to buy real estate with cryptocurrencies in Montenegro?
content_en: (Photo: Shutterstock.com/Julien Tromeur) At a time when cryptocurrencies are setting records, and the value of the real estate market is growing at a rapid rate, the question arises whether it is possible to buy an apartment or a house in Montenegro and pay with bitcoins? The answer is - yes. Namely, despite the fact that Montenegro does not yet have a regulated crypto-property law, some agencies offer the possibility of paying for real estate with crypto-currencies. According to unofficial information, some transactions were also carried out, so by the end of last year, three notarial records were drawn up on the purchase and sale of cryptocurrencies. - There are real estate agencies in Montenegro, especially in coastal cities like Budva and Tivat, which offer the possibility of paying for real estate with cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ethereum. Also, some luxury resorts promoted this option with the aim of attracting foreign investors. Although there are reports on realized sales, they cannot be submitted to other persons for review, so specific examples are not widely documented. However, according to some unofficial information, by the end of 2024, three notarial records on the purchase and sale of cryptocurrencies have been drawn up - Radoš Kuč, founder of the Digitron Accounting agency, said in an interview for eKapija. How does it all work? Kuč states that Montenegro still does not have a regulated law on crypto-assets, and since it is not included in the Government`s plans for 2025, it is expected to be adopted next year. - When it comes to the purchase of real estate with cryptocurrencies, such trade exists, although it is not legally regulated. The value in the sales contract is expressed in fiat currencies, i.e. in euros, which is indicated in the contract. Transactions are usually completed before notarization and are carried out through digital wallets, since there is no exchange office for cryptocurrencies in Montenegro. Therefore, the conversion is most often carried out via foreign platforms - says Kuch. As he explains, the purchase and sale contract for real estate must be expressed in euros, as it is the official currency of Montenegro. - Cryptocurrency payments are usually made before the contract is verified, through a blockchain transaction, which can be verified within minutes. The seller confirms the receipt of the funds, and the notary relies on this confirmation in order to issue a clausula intabulandi, by which the seller expresses his consent for the buyer to be registered as the owner - Kuč states. When asked whether foreigners can even bring cryptocurrencies into the country and use them to finance the purchase of real estate, our interlocutor answers in the affirmative. - Foreigners can bring cryptocurrencies into Montenegro and use them to buy real estate under the same conditions as domestic citizens, but, as I already mentioned, the legal regulation does not exist, which creates legal uncertainty and a lot of ambiguity. There was a similar situation in the region, for example in Serbia, before the adoption of the law. That is exactly why I focused on this area and started cooperation with Miloš Praštal, the first crypto accountant from Serbia. Our plan is first of all education, and when the law is adopted, specialization for that area in Montenegro - says Kuč. We were also interested in how real estate tax is paid. Kuč clarifies that from January 1, 2024, Montenegro applies a progressive tax on the sale of real estate, according to the following rates Up to EUR 150,000.00 3%; From EUR 150,000.01: EUR 4,500.00 + 5% on the amount over EUR 150,000.01; From EUR 500,000.01: EUR 22,000.00 + 6% on the amount over EUR 500,000.01. - The tax is paid exclusively in euros, regardless of whether the payment was made in cryptocurrencies. The tax liability is reported to the Tax Administration, and in most cases, the notary submits the tax return on behalf of the party when certifying the contract. It is important to note that VAT is additionally payable for new construction . It is also the duty of notaries to submit contracts on the purchase and sale of cryptocurrencies to the Police Directorate and the Department for Financial Intelligence (FIU) - says Kuč. When it comes to capital gain, says Kuč, in theory, it arises when a natural person sells assets (which can also be cryptocurrencies) at a price higher than the purchase value. - The rate of tax on capital gains is 15%, and natural persons are required to submit an annual tax return no later than March 31 of the current year for profits realized in the previous year. This process can be complex due to the volatility of cryptocurrencies and the need to prove the purchase price, which requires keeping a record of transactions, he says. And do banks allow funds from cryptocurrencies to be converted and deposited into the seller`s account before the sale? The interlocutor of eKapija says that banks in Montenegro do not support direct transactions with cryptocurrencies due to the lack of regulation and strict rules, which to some extent led to the withdrawal of one regional crypto-exchange from the Montenegrin market. - That is why today in Montenegro there are no regulated crypto-exchanges or payment providers mediating these transactions. However, funds from cryptocurrencies can be converted into euros via foreign platforms and paid into the seller`s account, but banks often require proof of the origin of the money, which can complicate the process - says Kuč. When asked about the risks when it comes to buying real estate in cryptocurrencies, Kuč explains that it is more of a legal issue, which he would not give an answer to. - Precisely for this reason, our first goal is an education where, in addition to crypto accountants, lawyers with experience in this field would also participate - concludes Kuč in an interview with eKapija. They sell apartments, houses, lots and cars for cryptocurrencies As BIRN recently wrote, apartments, houses, lots and cars can be bought for cryptocurrencies on the Facebook ad space and numerous websites for the sale of vehicles and real estate in Montenegro. Cryptocurrencies can be used to pay for real estate in the luxury complexes of the company Dukley gardens and Dukley residence in Budva since December 2017. That company did not disclose how many properties in luxury complexes were purchased with digital money. BIRN research from December 2023 showed that real estate in Montenegro is most often bought by citizens of Russia, Ukraine, Cyprus, the United Arab Emirates, Israel, and the United States. - The best locations for buying real estate with cryptocurrencies are Budva, Kotor, Bar, Herceg Novi and Ulcinj - it is stated on the website of one of the real estate agencies that offers the possibility of buying with cryptocurrencies. In September last year, the Ministry of Finance announced that, in cooperation with the Central Bank and the Capital Market Commission, they are working on a law that would regulate the field of digital assets.
