In un momento in cui le criptovalute raggiungono nuovi massimi e il mercato immobiliare registra una rapida crescita, si pone la domanda se sia possibile acquistare un immobile in Montenegro pagando in bitcoin. La risposta è affermativa. Nonostante l’assenza di una normativa specifica sulle cripto-attività nel Paese, alcune agenzie immobiliari – soprattutto nelle località costiere come Budva e Tivat – offrono la possibilità di pagare in criptovalute, tra cui Bitcoin ed Ethereum. Alcune vendite sono state effettivamente concluse: secondo informazioni non ufficiali, entro la fine del 2024 sono stati redatti tre atti notarili relativi a transazioni immobiliari pagate in criptovalute.

Radoš Kuč, fondatore dello studio contabile Digitron, ha spiegato in un’intervista a eKapija che, sebbene il Montenegro non abbia ancora adottato una legge sulle cripto-attività – e non sia prevista nel programma governativo per il 2025 – questa dovrebbe essere introdotta l’anno prossimo. Attualmente, i contratti di compravendita immobiliare devono indicare il prezzo in euro, valuta ufficiale del Paese, anche quando il pagamento avviene in criptovalute. Le transazioni sono solitamente concluse prima della stipula notarile, tramite portafogli digitali e piattaforme estere, dato che nel Paese non esistono sportelli di cambio autorizzati per criptovalute.

Il compratore invia i fondi tramite blockchain, il venditore conferma il ricevimento e il notaio, sulla base di tale conferma, emette la clausola intabulandi per il trasferimento della proprietà. Gli stranieri possono utilizzare criptovalute per acquistare immobili alle stesse condizioni dei cittadini locali, ma la mancanza di regolamentazione crea incertezza giuridica.

Dal 1° gennaio 2024, il Montenegro applica un’imposta progressiva sulle vendite immobiliari: 3% fino a 150.000 euro, 4.500 euro più il 5% sulla parte eccedente fino a 500.000 euro, e 22.000 euro più il 6% oltre tale soglia. L’imposta va pagata esclusivamente in euro, indipendentemente dalla valuta di pagamento. Inoltre, per gli immobili di nuova costruzione si applica l’IVA. I notai sono tenuti a trasmettere i contratti alla Direzione di Polizia e all’Unità di Informazione Finanziaria (FIU).

In caso di plusvalenze da criptovalute, la tassazione è del 15% e richiede la presentazione annuale della dichiarazione entro il 31 marzo. Le banche montenegrine non supportano transazioni dirette con criptovalute a causa dell’assenza di regole chiare, costringendo gli operatori a ricorrere a piattaforme estere per la conversione in euro, con richieste frequenti di tracciabilità delle somme.

Per questi motivi, Kuč e il collega Miloš Praščal, primo “crypto commercialista” della Serbia, stanno avviando iniziative formative per preparare professionisti specializzati, in vista dell’adozione della futura legge. Complessi di lusso come Dukley Gardens e Dukley Residence a Budva accettano pagamenti in criptovalute già dal 2017. Secondo ricerche di BIRN, gli acquirenti stranieri provengono soprattutto da Russia, Ucraina, Cipro, Emirati Arabi Uniti, Israele e Stati Uniti, e le località più richieste per acquisti con criptovalute sono Budva, Kotor, Bar, Herceg Novi e Ulcinj.

Per le imprese italiane attive nel settore immobiliare o nei servizi legali e contabili specializzati, questa situazione rappresenta un’opportunità per supportare investitori interessati al mercato montenegrino, anticipando l’entrata in vigore della normativa in via di definizione.
title_it: Acquisti immobiliari con criptovalute in Montenegro

title_en: Vladimir and Petar Veličković, founders of the company Bravera - After the largest retail park, we want to build a high-class hotel in Bijelo Polje
content_en: The brothers Vladimir and Petar Veličković (Photo: Bravera) Bravera City Park, the largest retail center in Montenegro and the region, was recently opened in the Bjelo Polje industrial zone, on the site of the former Yugoslav giant Vunk. Around 240 workers found work in more than 30 shops, and Bijelo Polje is once again becoming what it was for centuries - an important trade center. Behind this project stands the Veličković family, brothers Vladimir and Petar, who have been investing in their city for more than three decades. And they don`t intend to stop, on the contrary. As they said in the interview for eKapija, the second phase of the development of Bravera City Park is also planned, within which sports fields will be built. And on one of the best locations in Bijelo Polje, they want to build a high-class hotel. This successful business story began in the early nineties, and despite numerous challenges, Bravera grew from a one-employee company into a large family-owned company known throughout the region. What is the secret of their success? First of all, in love, our interlocutors say. Love for the family, but also for the hometown. Because they have shown how much they love their city and all the people in it with the numerous projects they have initiated, but which they are still planning to implement. When you founded Bravera in 1991, what was your biggest motivation and biggest fear? How did you manage to maintain and develop the company in those challenging times when many gave up? - Although it was a period when social enterprises operated in the entire region and private entrepreneurship was just beginning to develop, the idea was born to try our hand at this new business world. The opening of a private enterprise gave some hope, but the chances of making something significant, besides large social enterprises, were very slim. While many chose security and a job in state-owned enterprises and institutions, we decided to take a step into the unknown. We founded the company on July 12, 1991 and gave it the unique, short name BRAVERA. Everything is woven into the name itself: BRA-brothers VE-Veličković RA-Rasovo . The name is short, sonorous, and clear - and the meaning emphasizes fraternal harmony and love, as well as his native place, Rasovo. Fear was also born because it was a journey into the unknown. Although engineers by profession, we started in the direction of trade and established cooperation with the then large state trading companies. The main motive was to provide a better life and better conditions for expanding the family. Petar Veličković (Photo: Bravera) Did you initially believe that you would grow from a small family business to a company of this scale? How important are family, community and local affiliation for your business journey? - Each of our beginnings, including this one, contained planning and analysis, and that`s when the idea was born that a small company with one employee would someday become a reputable family company, but not on the scale it is today. We had no idea that we were about to start writing history. Brotherly love, the help of sisters (lawyer and economist), the vision of the construction and mechanical engineer brothers, were the backbone of the very beginning of the company. The greatest desire and idea for the formation of a private company was given by older brother Vladimir. He came up with the name and gave the guidelines for the development of the family business, which the rest of us looked at in disbelief. It was also the first job for the younger brother. That`s when the family began to expand, so a real struggle was being waged at the same time. The struggle for survival and existence as 1992 and 1993 come. War events in the region, hyperinflation, etc. Our love for our hometown kept us going even then, so we only did business in Bijelo Polje and opened more retail stores in our city. Family harmony and love played a decisive role in the development of a successful business path, and as the children grew up, they supported us, got involved in the work and became important members of the family company. Bravera City Park (Photo: Bravera) The Nike Shop in Bijelo Polje was a big step forward – what did the opening of that facility mean to you in 1999? Did you feel at that time that you were creating something that would mark the north of Montenegro? - The opening of that facility in that period was certainly the biggest thing up to that time. A big thing for our small company, our family, for our city and the whole north of Montenegro, because it was the only Nike shop in the north. At that time, Bijelo Polje shone on the map and was the only one in the region with a specialized shop of the world`s largest manufacturer of sports equipment. The fact that we opened the Nike shop on March 2, 1999, and the bombing began on March 24 and brought many problems, shows that everything was difficult and uncertain back then. Difficult conditions for the procurement of goods, the introduction of sanctions and bans on imports, the mobilization of the local population and many other problems. After a short period, this Nike shop grew into a multi-brand sports equipment shop, because at that time it was easier to get different brands and sell them than the world`s best brand. How did the cooperation with Sport Vision come about and what does that partnership mean to you? - In the first decade of business, we cooperated with several partners, distributors and sports equipment wholesalers. Along the way, we got to know the owners and people from Sport Vision (they had a different name then) and found great understanding and help in solving the problems we had in a small environment. Our business cooperation has grown into more of a fraternal than a business relationship. This is how we got the best partners and friends for life, which we are particularly proud of. Our cooperation has led us to the formation of a joint company in Montenegro and to results that are worthy of every respect. Bravera City Park (Photo: Bravera) Recently, Bravera City Park was opened in Bijelo Polje. What does this project mean for Bijelo Polje and northern Montenegro? What is your personal emotion when you know that you are building the largest retail park in Montenegro right in your hometown and right on the Vunk area, the former symbol of the city? - After the expansion of our business and the opening of facilities outside our hometown, there was always a desire to somehow repay our city and to never forget our city. This is where we were born, grew up, made the best friends, formed families. This is where all our children were born. This is where our parents and our ancestors lived, which we are particularly proud of. We rightly point out that there was always a desire, which came true this year. "A desire that returns the warmth of home, strong as a house and beautiful as a white field." By investing this much in our city, we showed how much we love our hometown and all the people in it. We are giving Bijelo Polje a new shine and returning it to where it has been for centuries - an important shopping center and gathering place. Now, Bijelo Polje has the biggest retail park in Montenegro and the region. It once again becomes a regional shopping center where citizens of the whole region will gather, as well as tourists on their way to the sea. Around 240 workers found employment here, and the contents were completed by over 30 companies with the same offer as the biggest shopping centers. It is a special charm to be on the site of the former Vunko plant, which was a symbol of the Bjelopolje economy, but also of the entire country. Of course, we do not compare ourselves to that giant because he employed many workers and built Bijelo Polje, but for the last decade and longer, this area was in a very unenviable position and an area from which the eye was averted. Now it is a new gathering place and center of large events and events. After only a few months of operation, the benefits of the municipality of Bijelo Polje and the entire north are clear. What do you say to young people who want to build a business in small communities, but face big obstacles? - We tell the younger generations that they should believe in success, but also to persevere because they will certainly encounter a lot of problems. The reality is that young people choose their own path, and along the way they are often separated from their families and their hometowns. It is a reality, but you should never neglect or forget about your family, your loved ones, your hometown. We tell our young fellow citizens that everyone is guided by fate and the desire for a better life, but the homeland remains the most beautiful and sacred thing. When there is also the possibility of employment, the message is clear - you should stay or come back. Such people and such nature are not found anywhere. There are always ideas, and those who really want to work can live and create above the national average here. Bravera City Park construction site (Photo: Bravera) Your company is known for its donations and community support, so even the opening of Bravera City Park was marked by donations. How important is socially responsible business to you, and do you consider it a duty or a personal mission? - As a small company with one employee, we always tried to help and donate. As we have grown into a successful company, our donations have become bigger and more frequent. We are of the opinion that it is the duty of every person and every institution, and above all it is a personal mission. The opening of Bravera City Park creates an opportunity to help the local community and individuals even more, especially the most vulnerable categories. A part of the profit is set aside for these purposes. Do you think that Bijelo Polje is ready for even bigger investments and development projects? How do you envision the city in the next 10 - 20 years and where do you see Bravera on that path? - Despite the fact that it is often mentioned that young people are leaving the north of Montenegro and that the number of inhabitants is decreasing, we believe that Bijelo Polje has a perspective and that it has good and serious individuals and companies ready for even bigger investments and development projects. Of course, even greater state support is needed. Bijelo Polje has a great potential for tourism, hospitality and food production, so we are developing Bravera in that direction. Bravera City Park (Photo: Bravera) What are your plans for the following period? Are there any other projects in the pipeline in Bijelo Polje, and in the whole of Montenegro? - Given that this was a big project for us, the continuation and realization of the next projects will go a little slower, but it is certain that another very important investment will soon begin at a location that is one of the best in Bijelo Polje, where we hope to build a high-class hotel with some of the renowned European names in the hotel industry with all the accompanying facilities. Construction of sports fields and other facilities is also planned in the second phase of Bravera City Park. Also, Bravera will soon start building an apartment-type facility in Žabljak and then in Podgorica. Finally, we have a message for all future generations: In difficult times and difficult circumstances, building a company was madness for many. When fraternal harmony, love and family are the foundation, everything that is built is illuminated by victory. However, it is possible to make childhood dreams come true, even more than that... content_it:
I fratelli Vladimir e Petar Veličković, fondatori dell’azienda Bravera, hanno inaugurato recentemente a Bijelo Polje, in Montenegro, il Bravera City Park: il più grande centro commerciale del Paese e dell’intera regione, realizzato nell’area dell’ex stabilimento jugoslavo Vunk. Circa 240 persone hanno trovato impiego presso oltre 30 negozi, contribuendo a rilanciare Bijelo Polje come storico centro commerciale.

Attivi da oltre trent’anni nella propria città, i Veličković non intendono fermarsi: è già in programma la seconda fase dello sviluppo del parco, con la costruzione di campi sportivi, e stanno valutando la realizzazione di un hotel di alto livello in una delle posizioni più pregiate della città.

L’avventura imprenditoriale è iniziata nel 1991, in un contesto di transizione economica e instabilità, con una piccola attività a conduzione familiare che oggi è diventata un gruppo noto in tutta la regione. Il segreto del loro successo, spiegano, è l’amore per la famiglia e per la comunità d’origine.

Tra i traguardi più significativi, l’apertura nel 1999 del primo negozio Nike del nord del Montenegro, nonostante il difficile contesto bellico e le sanzioni internazionali, e la successiva collaborazione con Sport Vision, trasformatasi in una partnership strategica e in una joint venture nel Paese.

Particolarmente sentito è il loro impegno sociale: parte degli utili viene regolarmente destinata a sostegno delle fasce più vulnerabili della popolazione locale. Per i Veličković, la responsabilità sociale non è solo un dovere, ma una missione personale.

Guardando al futuro, l’azienda prevede nuovi investimenti anche a Žabljak e Podgorica, con la costruzione di complessi residenziali. Secondo i fondatori, Bijelo Polje possiede un grande potenziale turistico e agroalimentare, e con adeguato sostegno pubblico può attrarre ulteriori investimenti di rilievo.

Per le imprese italiane attive nel settore alberghiero di alta gamma, nei servizi di ristorazione e nella realizzazione di strutture sportive, questa espansione apre opportunità concrete di collaborazione con un gruppo locale solido e orientato alla crescita sostenibile.
title_it: Hotel di lusso a Bijelo Polje dopo il parco commerciale

title_en: Bill on Legalization in parliamentary procedure by end of October
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Freepik / jcomp) Serbian Prime Minister Djuro Macut has stated that the Bill on Special Conditions for the Recording and Registration of Ownership Rights to Real Estate, which will be on the agenda of the Government session today, will be sent to the National Assembly for consideration immediately after adoption, the Serbian Government announced. In an interview with Radio-Television of Serbia (RTS), Macut expressed his expectation that the proposed law would be adopted in late October or early November, and that its implementation would begin by the end of the year. He expressed his hope that the bill would be included in the agenda of the regular autumn session that day and that it would receive broad support in the parliament. – This is one of the historic pieces of news that fundamentally changes the perception of the state’s relationship with citizens’ property. The legalization process, which has been going on for decades, is now reaching its epilogue. This is a significant step forward that all citizens will recognize and understand. I do not expect that there will be grounds for questioning this law – the Prime Minister said. Macut recalled that, since the 1990s, there had been a problem with registering buildings that had not been legalized, stating that attempts had been made to stop this process in 2015 and 2016, but that approximately 300,000 such cases had been resolved thus far. According to him, more than four million buildings today have a certain degree of irregularity, which is an obstacle to their registration and legalization in terms of registering the ownership rights to these properties. He expressed his gratitude to the Ministry of Construction, Transport and Infrastructure and Minister Aleksandra Sofronijevic for their dedicated work and commitment in the process of adopting the new law. In cooperation with the Republic Geodetic Authority, a process has been initiated that resulted in the formation of a draft law that, in a simple way, enables the factual situation on the ground to be translated into a legal framework, the Prime Minister explained. This way, as he pointed out, all citizens who own real estate, real estate or buildings of importance will have the opportunity to be registered. Macut stated that the application would be electronic and that everything would be ready for the registration of the first applications by the end of the year. Speaking about the fees, he said that they had been significantly lowered and that they would be paid in relation to the size of the facility, square footage and the zones in which the facilities were located. Belgrade is probably the most complex area, given that there are several zones that are categorized, and accordingly the amount of the fee will vary from 100 to 1,000 euros, the Prime Minister pointed out, adding that in smaller cities and towns in the interior, the amount had been adjusted, starting from the lowest level, i.e. 100 euros. Vlada Republike Srbije Government of Serbia Đuro Macut Bill on Special Conditions for the Recording and Registration of Ownership Rights to Real Estate Bill on Legalization legalization of real estate Your comment Send
content_it:
Il primo ministro serbo Đuro Macut ha annunciato che il disegno di legge sulle “Condizioni speciali per la registrazione dei diritti di proprietà sugli immobili”, in discussione oggi in seno al Governo, sarà trasmesso immediatamente all’Assemblea Nazionale dopo la sua adozione. In un’intervista con la Radio-Televisione della Serbia (RTS), Macut ha espresso l’auspicio che la normativa venga approvata entro la fine di ottobre o agli inizi di novembre, con l’entrata in vigore prevista entro la fine dell’anno.  

Il premier ha definito questa legge “uno dei provvedimenti storici che modifica radicalmente il rapporto tra Stato e proprietà dei cittadini”, sottolineando che il processo di legalizzazione, avviato decenni fa, sta ora giungendo al suo epilogo. Ha inoltre ricordato che, dagli anni ‘90, persiste il problema della registrazione di edifici non legalizzati e che, nonostante i tentativi di risolverlo nel 2015 e 2016, finora sono stati regolarizzati circa 300.000 casi. Attualmente, oltre quattro milioni di edifici presentano irregolarità tali da ostacolarne la registrazione.  

Il procedimento sarà interamente digitale e le prime domande potranno essere presentate entro la fine dell’anno. Le tariffe, notevolmente ridotte, saranno calcolate in base alla superficie dell’immobile e alla zona in cui si trova: a Belgrado, dove le zone sono più differenziate, varieranno da 100 a 1.000 euro; nelle città minori e nell’entroterra si partirà da 100 euro.  

Macut ha ringraziato il Ministero delle Costruzioni, dei Trasporti e delle Infrastrutture e la ministra Aleksandra Sofronijević per il lavoro svolto, realizzato in collaborazione con l’Autorità Geodetica della Repubblica, che ha permesso di trasporre la situazione di fatto in un quadro giuridico semplice ed efficace.  

Questa riforma rappresenta un’opportunità per le imprese italiane attive nel settore delle infrastrutture, dell’edilizia e dei servizi tecnici, che potranno partecipare alla riqualificazione del patrimonio immobiliare serbo e supportare la transizione verso una maggiore formalizzazione del mercato immobiliare.
title_it: Legge sulla legalizzazione entro ottobre

title_en: Document on cooperation between VZ Moma Stanojlovic and Airbus Helicopters signed
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Shutterstock/Dario Valjan) A document on the continuation of the implementation of industrial cooperation projects between Serbia and Airbus, established on the basis of the contract for the procurement of H-145M helicopters, was signed in Belgrade. The document was signed by the Director of the Moma Stanojlovic Aviation Institute, Colonel Slavisa Pavlovic, the Head of Airbus Helicopters for Europe, Thomas Hain, and a representative of JP Jugoimport–SDPR. This way, the further engagement of VZ Moma Stanojlovic as a local manufacturer of helicopter components in the global Airbus supply chain is secured, which ensures continuity in the transfer of knowledge and the development of high-tech production in Serbia. By implementing this project, as announced, Serbia is strengthening its role in the international aviation industry and improving the capacities for long-term maintenance and development of its own helicopter fleet. content_it:
A Belgrado è stato firmato un documento per la prosecuzione dei progetti di cooperazione industriale tra la Serbia e Airbus, attuati in base al contratto per l’acquisto degli elicotteri H-145M. L’accordo è stato sottoscritto dal direttore dell’Istituto Aeronautico “Moma Stanojlović”, il colonnello Slaviša Pavlović, dal responsabile Airbus Helicopters per l’Europa, Thomas Hain, e da un rappresentante di JP Jugoimport–SDPR.  

L’intesa garantisce il proseguimento del coinvolgimento del VZ Moma Stanojlović quale produttore locale di componenti elicotteristici all’interno della catena globale di fornitura di Airbus, assicurando continuità nel trasferimento di conoscenze e nello sviluppo di una produzione ad alta tecnologia in Serbia.  

Grazie a questa collaborazione, la Serbia rafforza il proprio ruolo nel settore aeronautico internazionale e migliora le proprie capacità per la manutenzione e lo sviluppo a lungo termine della flotta nazionale di elicotteri.  

Questa partnership rappresenta un’opportunità interessante per le imprese italiane specializzate nella subfornitura aerospaziale e nella produzione di componenti ad alta tecnologia.
title_it: Accordo VZ Moma Stanojlović-Airbus per elicotteri

title_en: Aleksandar Glavinic, Finance Manager at Mei Ta Europe – Controlling as a tool for making the right decisions
content_en: (Photo: Dušica Đermanović) Controlling is one of the pillars of efficient cost management in manufacturing companies. The controlling function is also applied at Mei Ta Europe in order to optimize processes and manage production costs more efficiently. Aleksandar Glavinic, Finance Manager at Mei Ta Europe, reveals how controlling is performed in this company. How important is controlling for business, especially in times of high raw material prices and market instability during the automotive industry crisis? – Controlling at Mei Ta Europe is not just cost monitoring, but strategic support to management. We focus on three pillars - cost transparency, planning and process efficiency. Production has two main phases - foundry and machining - and controlling monitors both through a system of standard costs per product and process. This way, we accurately identify deviations, bottlenecks and losses, and react quickly with corrective measures. In planning, we develop models for predicting raw material and energy prices, and we monitor efficiency through KPIs and benchmarking. In this way, controlling becomes a compass for making proactive decisions. As a finance manager in a company that operates globally, how do you deal with the complexity of import and export flows? – Mei Ta Europe is a company that simultaneously imports raw materials and markets products throughout the world market, and we face the challenges of global flows every day. The turbulence of the automotive industry market further complicates management, since the sector is under strong pressure from the energy transition, new regulations and changing consumer habits. Are you looking for new business models in this case? – We have established a business model that assumes that the price of raw materials is closely linked to the selling price of the product through contractual formulas. In this way, we amortize potentially negative effects and ensure relative stability of margins. In addition, we use hedging instruments, as well as natural hedges through the adjustment of foreign exchange inflows and outflows. With this approach, we can manage a complex supply and distribution chain, while at the same time ensuring the company’s financial stability and resilience to the challenges brought by today’s turbulent automotive industry environment. Modern investors and society are increasingly looking at the broader contribution of the company - not only through profit, but also through sustainability and social responsibility. How do you approach the process of making investment decisions at Mei Ta Europe, taking into account the impact on the environment and the contribution to local communities? How does the finance function support such a holistic approach? – I must emphasize that, in the company, we are aware of global trends and changing consumer awareness not only in the automotive industry but also beyond, and that we always try to view our investment decisions through three dimensions - profitability, sustainability and social impact. The finance sector is developing models that measure the benefits for society, not only for the company. What do you put special emphasis on? – We place special emphasis on the circular economy - recycling and reuse of materials, which reduces waste and conserves resources. At the same time, we develop green energy projects, which brings both environmental and financial benefits. In this way, Mei Ta Europe (MTE) together with the finance team, does not only look at the numbers, but at the bigger picture of the future of the company and the environment. How does MTE as a company balance between traditional operations in the fossil fuel sector and the need for transformation towards green technologies? – Our focus at MTE is on gradual diversification. We are aware that the global automotive industry is undergoing a transition towards sustainable mobility. Our approach is twofold: we optimize existing processes to reduce energy consumption and emissions, and in parallel we invest in new segments such as electric bicycles. This diversification allows for stable income from traditional operations, while we invest in green projects, ensuring long-term competitiveness and sustainability. How do you see the future of the automotive industry and the role of MTE in this transformation? – The industry is moving towards electrification, sustainable materials and smart mobility. However, the growth trend of electric vehicles is currently slowing down, and internal combustion engines will continue to have a significant share for a long time. Therefore, both segments will develop in parallel. Mei Ta Europe’s strategy is to make existing processes sustainable while investing in projects for electric and hybrid vehicles, as well as micromobility. In this way, we ensure a balance between the stability of the current business and preparation for the future. content_it:
Il controlling rappresenta uno dei pilastri della gestione efficiente dei costi nelle aziende manifatturiere. In Mei Ta Europe, questa funzione è impiegata non solo per monitorare i costi, ma come supporto strategico al management, basato su tre pilastri: trasparenza dei costi, pianificazione e efficienza dei processi. Aleksandar Glavinic, Finance Manager dell’azienda, spiega che il sistema di controlling si basa su costi standard per prodotto e processo, consentendo di identificare rapidamente deviazioni, colli di bottiglia e perdite. Attraverso modelli predittivi per materie prime ed energia, nonché indicatori di performance (KPI) e benchmarking, il controlling diventa una bussola per decisioni proattive.  

In un contesto di complessità legata ai flussi globali di import ed export, aggravata dalla transizione energetica e dai cambiamenti normativi nel settore automotive, Mei Ta Europe adotta un modello commerciale che collega contrattualmente il prezzo delle materie prime a quello di vendita, garantendo stabilità marginale. A ciò si aggiungono strumenti di copertura e natural hedge per gestire efficacemente la catena logistica e mantenere la resilienza finanziaria.  

Sul fronte degli investimenti, l’azienda adotta un approccio olistico valutando ogni decisione sotto tre dimensioni: redditività, sostenibilità e impatto sociale. Particolare attenzione è dedicata all’economia circolare – con riciclo e riuso dei materiali – e a progetti di energia verde, che generano benefici sia ambientali che economici.  

La strategia di Mei Ta Europe prevede una diversificazione graduale: da un lato, l’ottimizzazione dei processi esistenti per ridurre consumi ed emissioni; dall’altro, investimenti in nuovi segmenti come le biciclette elettriche e la micromobilità. In un settore automotive in transizione, l’azienda punta a bilanciare la stabilità delle operazioni tradizionali con la preparazione a un futuro più sostenibile.  

Per le imprese italiane attive nei settori della meccanica, della componentistica automotive o delle tecnologie verdi, questa evoluzione apre opportunità di collaborazione in ambiti quali l’efficienza energetica, l’economia circolare e la mobilità sostenibile.

title_en: IPMA Gold Award for MK Group and Palace of Science project
content_en: Aleksandra Stojanović, the project director of the Palace of Science and director of corporate affairs of MK Group (Photo: Jakov Simović) Prestigious world acknowledgment for project management excellence awarded for the first time to a project from Serbia MK Group has been awarded the prestigious IPMA Gold Award for global excellence in project management for the realization of the complex and most significant socially responsible endeavor, the opening of the Palace of Science, the Miodrag Kostić Endowment in Belgrade. First place and the gold award were presented to Aleksandra Stojanović, the project director, in the category of socially significant projects at the IPMA Global Awards Gala held on September 19 in Berlin. The IPMA Association ( International Project Management Association ) is the oldest professional global organization promoting professional project management according to international standards and is one of the most respected in this field, established in 1965, and it has awarded recognition to a project from Serbia for the first time. The Miodrag Kostić Endowment – Palace of Science, a unique center for the promotion of science, research, and innovation, has been recognized globally as an example of excellent project management and has undergone rigorous evaluation by international experts in project management, being declared the best project in the world by an international jury. The management of the project, led by Director Stojanović, included the reconstruction of a historical building, the development of educational and innovative content, the establishment of an organizational structure and a model for sustainable functioning, as well as a high level of social responsibility and community impact. Thanks to careful strategy and top-notch expertise, the Palace of Science has positioned itself as an international example of successful management of complex projects with long-term social benefits. – This award represents a great recognition for the entire team that participated in the realization of the Miodrag Kostić Endowment – Palace of Science, but also a confirmation that thoughtful management, a clear vision, and consistent implementation are the keys to the success of any complex project. I owe special thanks to the IPMA committee for recognizing the breadth and significance of this project – stated Aleksandra Stojanović, project director of the Science Palace and director of corporate affairs at MK Group . – It is a special honor for us that Serbia has won such a prestigious award for the first time. MK Group has proven through its expertise, dedication, and professionalism that our country is also worthy of global gold awards – said Marija Todorović, executive director of IPMA Serbia . IPMA is the oldest global organization in the field of project management, headquartered in Switzerland, and is present in over 70 countries worldwide. Through the Global Awards program, IPMA annually recognizes organizations that stand out according to the highest standards in planning, execution, and sustainability of projects with long-term social impact. The category of social regional development, in which MK Group won the gold award, brings together projects that change communities and build foundations for social progress. The significance of this award is further emphasized by the fact that among the previous winners in this category were institutions shaping the future of their communities, such as the Royal Commission of Saudi Arabia for the AlUla province project in that country, rich in cultural and archaeological heritage, the City of Cape Town in South Africa for the reconstruction and enhancement of the main public transport terminal in Cape Town, and others. MK Group d.o.o. content_it:
MK Group ha ricevuto il prestigioso IPMA Gold Award per l’eccellenza nella gestione del progetto del Palazzo della Scienza, Fondazione Miodrag Kostić a Belgrado. Si tratta del primo riconoscimento di questo livello assegnato a un progetto serbo dall’International Project Management Association (IPMA), organizzazione fondata nel 1965 e leader mondiale nella promozione degli standard internazionali di project management.

Il premio è stato consegnato il 19 settembre a Berlino ad Aleksandra Stojanović, direttrice del progetto e responsabile degli affari societari di MK Group, nella categoria dedicata ai progetti di rilevanza sociale. Il progetto, incentrato sulla ristrutturazione di un edificio storico e sulla creazione di un centro unico per la promozione della scienza, della ricerca e dell’innovazione, è stato valutato da una giuria internazionale come il migliore al mondo per la sua complessità, impatto sociale e sostenibilità.

La gestione del progetto ha incluso lo sviluppo di contenuti educativi, la definizione di una struttura organizzativa duratura e un forte impegno verso la responsabilità sociale. “Questo riconoscimento premia l’intero team e conferma che visione chiara, gestione accurata e implementazione coerente sono fondamentali per il successo di progetti complessi”, ha dichiarato Stojanović.

Marija Todorović, direttrice esecutiva di IPMA Serbia, ha sottolineato con orgoglio il traguardo storico: “È un onore che la Serbia riceva per la prima volta un premio di tale prestigio, a testimonianza della professionalità e dell’impegno delle nostre imprese”.

L’opportunità offerta da questo successo potrebbe interessare aziende italiane specializzate in restauro architettonico, sviluppo di contenuti educativi scientifici e gestione di progetti culturali complessi, in un contesto di crescente collaborazione tra Serbia e Unione Europea.
title_it: Premio IPMA Gold al progetto Palazzo della Scienza

title_en: Australians looking for gold 100 km from Belgrade – Company buys drilling rights on 62,000 hectares in Serbia, starting with Bobija
content_en: Bobija (Photo: eKapija / Aleksandra Kekić) Serbia continues to intrigue foreign mining companies; it seems they are racing to see who will be the first to stick a pickaxe in the search for Serbian precious metals. The latest example is the Australian Middle Island Resources, which, by taking over the company Konstantin Resources, also from Australia, became the owner of no less than 14 licenses for mineral exploration in Serbia, on as much as 62,000 hectares, which is more than any other company has in our country . The tenements comprise three main project areas - Bobija, Priboj, and Timok - which are considered primarily for gold and copper, as well as silver, lead, and zinc, as reported by Australia’s Mining. The Bobija project, on which the new owner will focus first, spans 208 square kilometers in central-western Serbia, about 100 km southwest of Belgrade. It includes three granted exploration licenses - Bobija, Bobija East and Kamenita Kosa - an application for Orovica and a 10-year option on two mining licenses from local firm Bobija doo Ljubovija. Gold literally peeking out from former baryte mine As Australian media report, Middle Island Resources has already begun field exploration, precisely at the Bobija project. This is the Bobija mountain near Ljubovija, where a baryte mine used to exist before, and the Australian company will seek gold and other valuable metals precisely there. Former baryte mine (Photo: eKapija / Aleksandra Kekić) Historic drilling from the 1960s to 1980s, and later work by Reservoir Minerals and Nevsun Resources in 2014-2017, intersected significant near-surface polymetallic mineralization in Triassic sediments, Australia’s Business News writes. One hole returned 45.2 meters at 1.71 grams per ton (g/t) gold, 25.5 g/t silver, 0.87 per cent lead and 2.26 per cent zinc from 18.8 m depth. A second hole assayed 15.1 m at 1.91 g/t gold, 122 g/t silver, 4.23 per cent lead and 4.73 per cent zinc from 38.9 m. – Recent work by Konstantin has revealed significant gold associated with the base metal mineralization historically targeted in the area – said Middle Island Resources non-executive director Daniel Raihani. Extensive massive sulfide mineralization is exposed in the floor of the historic open-pit mine and limited prior rock chip sampling by Konstantin (previously West End Resources) has highlighted high-grade potential, with results up to 5.24 g/t gold, 120 g/t silver, 4.66 per cent zinc and 4.36 per cent lead. Middle Island says that the site shares similarities with Adriatic Metals’ Vares project in Bosnia and Herzegovina, a high-grade polymetallic deposit estimated to contain 20.9 million tons of ore. Soil sampling is underway across the broader Bobija granted tenement area to follow up on 2024 stream sediment anomalies in gold and base metals, targeting historic workings where multiple baryte and sulfide sites were noted in government-era reports, including the Tisovik lead mine and Rebelj copper mine, reports Business News. What do we know about Middle Island Resources? Middle Island Resources is not a major player in the global mining market, but with an exploration area in Australia covering 860,000 hectares, and with the potential for copper and gold discoveries in Serbia, along with, as Business News reports, “modern Serbian mining legislation and developed infrastructure, the company is in a position to make a breakthrough in this fertile mining region.” The company announced on September 2 that it was acquiring Konstantin Resources Limited for AUD 9.5 million, paid for through 475 million of its shares, but the transaction requires shareholder approval, which is expected in late October or early November. The acquisition is said to be part of Middle Island’s strategy to transform itself into a global copper and gold explorer, and is supported by a parallel share issue worth AUD 3.4 million to fund exploration. The potential in Serbia has excited traders and investors who invest in companies listed on the Australian national stock exchange ASX (and Middle Island is among them), so one of them, Bhavdip Sanghavi, stated on his X account that this acquisition is a “game changer in one of the most promising mining belts in the world.” – Bobija shows all the characteristics of a discovery that can change a company. This is exactly how Adriatic Metals (which started as a small company and recently sold the mines in Vares to the Canadian company Dundee for USD 1.25 billion), created enormous value in the Balkans. Middle Island Resources could be next – believes this investor. B. P. content_it:
L’interesse internazionale per le risorse minerarie serbe continua a crescere. L’ultima azienda a entrare nel Paese è la australiana Middle Island Resources, che ha acquisito la connazionale Konstantin Resources, ottenendo 14 licenze di esplorazione su 62.000 ettari — la più vasta superficie detenuta da un’unica compagnia in Serbia. I progetti principali riguardano le aree di Bobija, Priboj e Timok, con obiettivi primari di oro e rame, oltre a argento, piombo e zinco.

L’attenzione iniziale si concentra sul progetto Bobija, situato circa 100 km a sudovest di Belgrado, che copre 208 km² e comprende tre licenze già concesse (Bobija, Bobija Est e Kamenita Kosa), una domanda in corso per Orovica e un’opzione decennale su due licenze minerarie della locale Bobija doo Ljubovija. L’area include una ex miniera di barite, dove le indagini storiche (anni ’60-’80) e i lavori successivi di Reservoir Minerals e Nevsun Resources (2014-2017) hanno intercettato significative mineralizzazioni polimetalliche vicino alla superficie. Tra i risultati più rilevanti: 45,2 metri con 1,71 g/t di oro, 25,5 g/t di argento, 0,87% di piombo e 2,26% di zinco.

Middle Island ha già avviato esplorazioni sul campo. Secondo il consigliere non esecutivo Daniel Raihani, “lavori recenti di Konstantin hanno rivelato oro significativo associato alla mineralizzazione di metalli base”. Campionamenti superficiali hanno mostrato valori fino a 5,24 g/t di oro, 120 g/t di argento, 4,66% di zinco e 4,36% di piombo. Il sito presenta affinità con il progetto Vares di Adriatic Metals in Bosnia ed Erzegovina, che contiene stime di 20,9 milioni di tonnellate di minerale.

L’azienda, pur non essendo un grande operatore globale, punta a trasformarsi in un esploratore internazionale di rame e oro. Ha annunciato l’acquisizione di Konstantin Resources per 9,5 milioni di dollari australiani, finanziata con l’emissione di azioni e un ulteriore collocamento da 3,4 milioni per sostenere le attività esplorative. L’operazione, soggetta all’approvazione degli azionisti entro novembre, ha generato entusiasmo tra gli investitori ASX, con alcuni che vedono in Bobija un potenziale “game changer” paragonabile al successo di Adriatic Metals nei Balcani.

Questo rinnovato interesse per le risorse minerarie serbe, sostenuto da una legislazione moderna e da infrastrutture sviluppate, potrebbe rappresentare un’opportunità per imprese italiane specializzate in macchinari per l’estrazione, tecnologie geologiche o servizi di supporto minerario.
title_it: Australiani cercano oro vicino a Belgrado

title_en: Serbia and French corporation Dassault aviation to launch joint projects in military aviation – Industrial Cooperation Agreement signed
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Maksimilian/shutterstock.com) The Serbian Ministry of Defense and the French company Dassault aviation signed today a special Industrial Cooperation Agreement, which opens up space for the development and production of weapons and military equipment in cooperation with the domestic defense industry and the Military Technical Institute. The signing of this document, as announced by the Ministry of Defense, created the conditions for joint projects in the aviation domain, and the signing of individual contracts between the companies is also envisaged. They will include technical assistance, as well as the transfer of technology and knowledge, which will enable the strengthening of domestic development and production capacities. This agreement means that the domestic defense industry will gain access to modern technological solutions and expertise of one of the world’s leading manufacturers in the aviation industry. The agreement was signed by Major General Slavko Rakic and Senior Vice President of Dassault aviation Jean-Claude Piccirillo. content_it: Il Ministero della Difesa serbo e la società francese Dassault Aviation hanno firmato oggi un Accordo di Cooperazione Industriale che apre la strada allo sviluppo e alla produzione congiunta di armamenti e equipaggiamenti militari, in collaborazione con l’industria nazionale della difesa e l’Istituto Tecnico Militare. Secondo quanto annunciato dal Ministero, l’accordo crea le condizioni per progetti comuni nel settore aeronautico e prevede anche la stipula di contratti specifici tra le aziende coinvolte. Questi includeranno assistenza tecnica, trasferimento di tecnologia e know-how, rafforzando così le capacità nazionali di sviluppo e produzione. L’intesa consentirà all’industria serba della difesa di accedere alle soluzioni tecnologiche e all’esperienza di uno dei principali produttori mondiali nel settore aeronautico. L’accordo è stato firmato dal Maggiore Generale Slavko Rakić e dal Senior Vice President di Dassault Aviation, Jean-Claude Piccirillo. Tale collaborazione potrebbe rappresentare un'opportunità per le imprese italiane attive nella subfornitura aerospaziale o nei sistemi di difesa avanzati, qualora fossero interessate a integrarsi in catene del valore internazionali legate a progetti di questa portata.

title_en: Sombor-based Black Horse factory, sole local car battery manufacturer, restarting production and planning new jobs
content_en: (Photo: Joe Belanger/shutterstock.com) Sombor-based Black Horse, the sole local car battery manufacturer, announced that it would hire 60 more workers by the end of the year and start trial production in mid-January. As announced by CEO Aleksandar Colic, new technology, aligned with European standards, will arrive at the Sombor factory in September, while the start of production of starter batteries is planned for next year. The company currently employs around 20 people, and from September the team should be expanded by an additional 60 people. With the launch of the starter battery production program, the plan is to hire around 100 more workers next year. The company’s vision is to have between 300 and 350 employees in Sombor by 2030. Since recently, the Black Horse FAS company is owned by RAIMS Capital. title_en: Flender from Subotica laying off more than 300 workers
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Oleg Golovnev/shutterstock.com) The Flender factory, which operates in the Industrial Park in Subotica, intends to lay off between 340 and 350 workers at the beginning of October. According to information unofficially confirmed to Politika, around 300 workers have voluntarily applied to leave the factory with severance pay. In addition, a number of other workers will be placed on the layoff list, some of whom will be redirected to the National Employment Service, while a smaller number of former Flender workers will be taken over by some of the companies operating in the Industrial Zone in Mali Bajmok. According to information from the factory, a large number of workers have voluntarily applied to leave the company because they managed to obtain favorable severance pay in negotiations with the company’s management. However, according to Politika, negotiations are still underway at the factory on the conditions and the final number of workers who will be laid off. This is by the way, the largest number of workers to be laid off at one time in one of the companies in the Industrial Zone Mali Bajmok. The Flender factory operates in the free zone regime. This is not the first time that Flender has laid off workers. Last year, a total of 180 workers were laid off on two occasions, mostly through severance agreements. The data presented in the company’s business results indicate that it had just over 1,200 workers at the end of last year. Business results show that the highest ones of the previous three years were those in 2023, while last year’s revenues were lower than in 2022 and amounted to just under 5.5 billion dinars, while profit was just over 123 million dinars, the lowest in the previous three years. Flender has been operating in Subotica since September 2020 and is engaged in the production of electric motors, generators and transformers. However, the factory has actually been present in Subotica since 2003, when it was part of the Flender Group as Loher Elektro. From 2005 to 2015, it operated within Siemens Group. Flender d.o.o. content_it:
Lo stabilimento Flender, situato nella Zona Industriale di Subotica, prevede di licenziare tra 340 e 350 dipendenti all’inizio di ottobre. Secondo informazioni riportate da Politika, circa 300 lavoratori hanno già presentato domanda volontaria di uscita, ottenendo un’indennità di licenziamento favorevole grazie a trattative con la direzione aziendale. Ulteriori esuberi saranno gestiti con il supporto del Servizio Nazionale per l’Impiego, mentre una parte più ridotta dei dipendenti licenziati sarà assorbita da altre imprese del parco industriale di Mali Bajmok.

Si tratta del più consistente taglio occupazionale mai registrato in un’unica soluzione all’interno della zona industriale di Mali Bajmok. Flender opera in regime di zona franca e non è la prima volta che attua riduzioni del personale: nel corso dello scorso anno furono licenziate complessivamente 180 persone, prevalentemente tramite accordi di esodo incentivato.

I dati finanziari indicano che alla fine del 2023 l’azienda contava poco più di 1.200 dipendenti. Sebbene i ricavi abbiano raggiunto quasi 5,5 miliardi di dinari, risultando inferiori rispetto al 2022, l’utile netto è sceso a poco più di 123 milioni di dinari, il valore più basso degli ultimi tre anni.

Flender è presente a Subotica dal 2003, inizialmente come Loher Elektro, parte del Gruppo Flender, e dal 2005 al 2015 ha fatto parte del Gruppo Siemens. La società Flender d.o.o. Subotica produce motori elettrici, generatori e trasformatori ed è attiva nella sua attuale configurazione dal settembre 2020.

La situazione potrebbe rappresentare un’opportunità per aziende italiane attive nel settore della subfornitura elettromeccanica o interessate a ricollocare professionalità specializzate nel campo dei motori elettrici.

title_en: Swarovski planning to place more products from Subotica on world market
content_en: (Photo: Youtube/Screenshot/  RTV Yu Eco) Minister of Economy Adrijana Mesarovic visited the Swarovski company, which operates in the Mali Bajmok industrial zone in Subotica, and on that occasion discussed with the management the continuation of cooperation and new projects, as well as the possibility of the company placing more products on the world market. – The most important thing for me is that I heard the message from them that they plan to continue and develop their business in our country, and that we will fight for more and more products from the Serbian market to take as much primacy and participation as possible on the world market – said Mesarovic after visiting the factory and meeting with management representatives. This company is engaged in the production and processing of crystals in Serbia and employs over 300 people, mostly from Subotica and the surrounding area. – As one of five Swarovski factories in the world, it is particularly important because as much as 55% of all Swarovski figurines sold worldwide are produced right here in Serbia. In addition, other products are also created in this factory, including a personalized program and a jewelry program – said the minister. La ministra dell’Economia Adrijana Mesarović ha visitato lo stabilimento Swarovski situato nella zona industriale di Mali Bajmok a Subotica, dove ha discusso con la direzione aziendale il prosieguo della collaborazione, nuovi progetti e la possibilità di collocare una quota ancora maggiore di prodotti sul mercato globale.  

«Ciò che più mi rincuora è stato sentire direttamente dall’azienda la volontà di proseguire e ampliare le proprie attività nel nostro Paese. Lavoreremo affinché sempre più prodotti di origine serba possano conquistare una posizione di rilievo sui mercati internazionali», ha dichiarato la ministra al termine dell’incontro.  

Lo stabilimento di Subotica, attivo nella produzione e lavorazione di cristalli, impiega oltre 300 persone, prevalentemente residenti nella città e nel circondario. «Questo impianto riveste un’importanza strategica a livello globale: è uno dei soli cinque stabilimenti Swarovski al mondo ed è responsabile della produzione del 55% delle statuine Swarovski commercializzate a livello internazionale. Oltre a queste, vengono realizzati anche articoli nell’ambito di programmi personalizzati e di gioielleria», ha aggiunto la ministra.  

L’espansione delle esportazioni di prodotti di alta gamma da Subotica offre interessanti opportunità per fornitori e partner industriali italiani nel settore della lavorazione di materiali di pregio e della componentistica per il lusso.

title_en: Ugljevik Mine and Thermal Power Plant in debt, Slovenians awaiting payments
content_en: (Photo: Shutterstock/DusanNN) The Ugljevik Mine and Thermal Power Plant (RiTE Ugljevik) has no money to pay its due obligations to the Slovenian Elektrogospodarstvo, which is why it is issuing shares worth 27.5 million convertible marks, which should be purchased by Maticno preduzece Elektroprivreda RS (parent company). The proposal for a decision on the issuance of shares will be discussed at the Shareholders’ Meeting scheduled for October 16. It is already clear from the proposal that the decision will be given the green light and that Maticno preduzece, as the majority shareholder, will purchase shares in the amount of about 20 million, which is currently the amount of the due debt to the Slovenians. It is also clear that another issue of 20 million will be needed to settle its obligations to the Slovenians for this year, given that two more installments are due at the end of the year. As a reminder, RiTE Ugljevik was ordered by an arbitration decision of a court in Belgrade in mid-2023 to pay the Slovenian Elektrogospodarstvo EUR 67 million and the same amount in interest for undelivered electricity from 2011 to the beginning of 2022, and to deliver a third of the electricity produced to them as long as it is in operation. Arbitration decisions charge RiTE hundreds of millions of euros In the meantime, an amendment to the arbitration decision was made, which obliges RiTE to pay the Slovenians another EUR 62 million for undelivered electricity from 2022 to 2024. In early 2024, contracts were signed with the Slovenians for the delivery of electricity and the repayment of the principal of EUR 67 million, while at the end of that year, a contract was signed to settle the debt based on undelivered electricity from 2022 to early 2024 in the amount of EUR 62 million. The issue of interest of EUR 67 million and arbitration before the court in Washington, which the Slovenians initiated on the same basis, remains unresolved. RiTE paid the first installment of the principal under the agreement signed in early 2024, while problems began with the second one, because they failed to pay about 1 million convertible marks in interest. In the request to Maticno preduzece, the management of RiTE states that the third installment in the amount of about 10 million convertible marks with interest was due on June 30, as well as the first installment under the agreement signed in late 2024 in the amount of about 9.3 million convertible marks. They point out that they cannot secure that money from regular business activities, so they invited them to exercise their pre-emptive right and pay for shares in the amount of 20.07 million marks. Negotiations in final phase This request was considered by the management of Maticno preduzece, which in its conclusion states that this year, obligations of approximately 20 million convertible marks are due under the agreement on repayment of the principal of the debt, and another 20 million convertible marks of obligations under the agreement on the recognition and settlement of the debt for undelivered electricity from the beginning of 2022 to January 31, 2024. – Given the fact that Maticno preduzece is not able to secure 40 million in the account that it would reserve for the implementation of the RiTE Ugljevik share issue for 2025, the management is of the opinion that two share issues of 20 million each should be made – the management’s conclusion states. As a reminder, RiTE Ugljevik is obliged to pay a total of approximately 372 million convertible marks to the Slovenian Elektrogospodarstvo by an arbitration decision of the court in Belgrade, which was made in mid-2023. Settlement agreements have been signed for most of that debt, while the issue of the payment of EUR 67 million remains unresolved and is currently under negotiation. RS Minister of Energy and Mining Petar Djokic recently said that the Slovenians had reduced the claim from EUR 67 million to EUR 37 million and that final talks on that were underway. Fotografije: Mješoviti Holding ERS - MP a.d. Trebinje - ZP RiTE Ugljevik A.D. Ugljevik Ministarstvo energetike i rudarstva RS Elektrogospodarstvo Slovenia Petar Đokić debts shares Your comment Send
content_it:
La miniera e la centrale termoelettrica di Ugljevik (RiTE Ugljevik) non dispone di liquidità sufficiente per onorare gli obblighi nei confronti dell’azienda slovena Elektrogospodarstvo e ha pertanto proposto l’emissione di azioni per 27,5 milioni di marchi convertibili, destinate all’acquisto da parte della società madre Maticno preduzece Elektroprivreda RS. Il consiglio di amministrazione prevede che l’assemblea degli azionisti, convocata per il 16 ottobre, approvi la delibera e che la società madre, in qualità di azionista di maggioranza, ne acquisti per circa 20 milioni, corrispondenti al debito corrente verso la controparte slovena.  

Tuttavia, servirà un’ulteriore emissione di azioni per altri 20 milioni per coprire le due rate ancora in scadenza entro fine anno.  

Il contenzioso ha origine da una sentenza arbitrale emessa da un tribunale di Belgrado a metà 2023, che ha condannato RiTE a pagare 67 milioni di euro, più interessi per lo stesso importo, per mancata fornitura di elettricità tra il 2011 e l’inizio del 2022, nonché a consegnare un terzo dell’elettricità prodotta finché l’impianto resterà in funzione. Successivamente, un emendamento alla sentenza ha aggiunto un ulteriore debito di 62 milioni di euro per elettricità non consegnata tra il 2022 e il 2024.  

Nel 2024 sono stati firmati accordi per la fornitura di energia e per il rimborso progressivo del capitale (67 milioni), mentre a fine anno è stato concluso un altro accordo per regolare il debito da 62 milioni relativo al periodo 2022–2024. Restano irrisolti la questione degli interessi (67 milioni) e un ulteriore procedimento arbitrale avviato dagli sloveni presso un tribunale di Washington.  

RiTE ha pagato la prima rata del capitale, ma ha incontrato difficoltà con la seconda, non riuscendo a versare circa 1 milione di marchi convertibili a titolo di interessi. Nella richiesta inviata alla società madre, la direzione di RiTE ha segnalato che al 30 giugno erano scadute la terza rata (circa 10 milioni più interessi) e la prima rata dell’accordo firmato a fine 2024 (circa 9,3 milioni). Non potendo reperire tali fondi dall’attività ordinaria, ha chiesto alla Maticno preduzece di esercitare il diritto di opzione per l’acquisto di azioni per 20,07 milioni di marchi.  

La direzione della società madre ha preso atto della situazione e ha concluso che nel 2024 sono in scadenza complessivamente 40 milioni di marchi: 20 milioni per il rimborso del capitale e altri 20 per il debito relativo all’elettricità non fornita tra inizio 2022 e il 31 gennaio 2024. Poiché non è in grado di accantonare l’intero importo in un’unica soluzione, propone di procedere con due emissioni distinte da 20 milioni ciascuna.  

Complessivamente, secondo la sentenza arbitrale di Belgrado, RiTE deve pagare circa 372 milioni di marchi convertibili all’Elektrogospodarstvo slovena. Sebbene la maggior parte del debito sia stata regolata con accordi transattivi, resta aperta la trattativa sugli interessi di 67 milioni. Il ministro serbo dell’Energia e delle Miniere, Petar Djokic, ha recentemente dichiarato che la controparte slovena ha ridotto la propria richiesta da 67 a 37 milioni di euro e che sono in corso colloqui finali per la definizione dell’accordo.  

La situazione evidenzia le crescenti pressioni finanziarie sul settore energetico serbo e potrebbe rappresentare un’opportunità per operatori esteri specializzati in ristrutturazioni aziendali o in fornitura di servizi tecnici e finanziari nel comparto energetico.
title_it: RiTE Ugljevik in difficoltà con debiti sloveni

title_en: RES Serbia 2025: Around 18 GW projects in the process of connection in our country
content_en: (Photo: Goran Zlatković) Renewable energy sources (RES) are the main driver of economic progress in many countries around the world. That our country is also keeping pace with the world was confirmed at the RES Serbia 2025 Conference in Vrdnik, whose media sponsor was the eKapija portal. There are currently around 18,000 MW of projects in Serbia in various stages of connection, of which 6,000 MW are in distribution. There are 6 gigawatts of demand in Montenegro, which is ten times more than Montenegro consumes at peak times, is the conclusion of a panel dedicated to transmission and distribution systems held at the RES SERBIA 2025 conference. Nebojsa Vucinic, Director of the Development Directorate of Elektromreza Srbije, pointed out that, the year before, they had had a surge in the preparation of connection studies, but that subsequently the number of requests had decreased. – It’s not just about the number of requests, that’s the least important thing. From the system point of view, megawatts are the most important. Currently, we have about 18,000 MW in the connection process in various stages, 6,000 MW in distribution plus transmission – Vucinic emphasized. 10 requests for independent battery storage, 2 for data centers He added that the data center industry was opening up and that EMS had 2 requests for these centers - one of 650 MW and the other of 100 MW. At the moment, 2,000 MW in batteries is in the connection process, which is 6 gigawatt-hours in power. 10 requests for independent battery storage are also in processing, it was stated at the RES SERBIA 2025 conference. – These are 10 facilities of 1,000 MW in total. We are preparing connection studies that will be finalized at the end of the year, after which we hope that they will submit bank guarantees. Storage facilities can play a significant role in the balancing process, perhaps even greater than pumped-storage hydropower plants – said Vucinic. He noted that EMS was working on capital projects to strengthen the system. – A few months ago, we marked the beginning of the construction of the third section of the Trans-Balkan Corridor, which is a capital project. It should be operational by the end of 2027. The second capital project is Beogrid, for which we laid the foundation stone near Dobanovci 10 days ago. Also, the delivery of a variable shunt reactor to Vranje is underway, since in Vranje we have the biggest problem with voltage conditions – Vucinic emphasized. 6 GW of demand in the distribution system Dalibor Nikolic, Director of the Technical System at Elektrodistribucija Srbije , stated that there were 2,400 active requests in the distribution system, which collectively had 6.1 GW, which was well above the maximum peak that the distribution system could achieve, in his assessment. – We started euphorically, liberally, and this led to serious congestion. We have a lot of projects that have started and have taken up space in the distribution system and we have to wait for time to pass for the space to be freed up. Analyses show that only 400 power plants are on the system. Of the submitted requests, less than 20% are feasible and realistic. The key moment came at the end of 2024, with the entry into force of amendments to the Energy Law, the rules of the game were introduced, and connection permits can only be extended once – Nikolic emphasized. There is also a large number of requests in Montenegro, 6 GW, revealed Aleksandar Mijuskovic, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Montenegrin Electric Transmission System. – We have 6 gigawatts of demand, and in Montenegro the maximum peak is 600 MW. We already have 10 times more demand than we consume at peak, we are facing the problem of how to connect everything – said Mijuskovic, adding that one of the most important projects, the Lastva-Pljevlja transmission line, would be completed by the end of the year, where only a few poles remained to be completed. The RES SERBIA 2025 conference was organized for the fifth time by the Association of Renewable Energy Sources of Serbia. content_it:
Le fonti rinnovabili (RES) rappresentano il principale motore di progresso economico in molti Paesi. Che anche la Serbia stia tenendo il passo con le tendenze globali è emerso chiaramente durante la conferenza RES Serbia 2025 tenutasi a Vrdnik, di cui eKapija è stato media sponsor. Attualmente sono circa 18.000 MW i progetti in varie fasi di connessione al sistema elettrico nazionale, di cui 6.000 MW riguardano la distribuzione. 

Nebojša Vučinić, direttore della Direzione Sviluppo di Elektromreža Srbije (EMS), ha sottolineato che, sebbene l’anno scorso vi sia stato un picco nelle richieste di studi di connessione, in seguito il numero di domande si è ridotto. “Non è il numero di richieste a contare, ma i megawatt. Attualmente abbiamo circa 18.000 MW in fase di connessione, tra trasmissione e distribuzione”. Ha inoltre riferito che sono in corso due richieste per data center (rispettivamente da 650 MW e 100 MW) e che circa 2.000 MW di capacità di accumulo tramite batterie — pari a 6 GWh — sono in fase di connessione. Sono inoltre in elaborazione 10 richieste per impianti indipendenti di accumulo, per un totale di 1.000 MW. “Gli impianti di stoccaggio potrebbero svolgere un ruolo nel bilanciamento del sistema anche superiore a quello degli impianti idroelettrici con pompaggio”, ha osservato Vučinić, ricordando che EMS sta portando avanti importanti investimenti infrastrutturali, tra cui il terzo tratto del Corridoio Trans-Balcanico (operativo entro fine 2027) e il progetto Beogrid, il cui avvio dei lavori è stato recentemente celebrato.

Dalibor Nikolić, direttore del Sistema Tecnico di Elektrodistribucija Srbije, ha evidenziato che nella rete di distribuzione sono attive 2.400 richieste per un totale di 6,1 GW, ben oltre la capacità massima della rete. “All’inizio si è proceduto in modo eccessivamente permissivo, causando congestione. Oggi meno del 20% delle richieste risulta realistico. Con le recenti modifiche alla legge energetica, entrate in vigore a fine 2024, le regole sono state definite più rigorosamente e i permessi di connessione possono essere prorogati una sola volta”.

Anche il Montenegro registra una situazione simile: Aleksandar Mijušković, presidente del Consiglio di Amministrazione del Gestore della Trasmissione Elettrica Montenegrina, ha rivelato una domanda di connessione pari a 6 GW, dieci volte superiore al picco di consumo nazionale (600 MW). “Stiamo lavorando al completamento della linea Lastva-Pljevlja entro la fine dell’anno”, ha aggiunto.

La conferenza RES Serbia 2025, giunta alla quinta edizione, è stata organizzata dall’Associazione delle Fonti di Energia Rinnovabile della Serbia. Per le imprese italiane specializzate in tecnologie per le energie rinnovabili, accumulo energetico e infrastrutture elettriche, il mercato serbo e balcanico offre opportunità significative, grazie all’ampio portafoglio di progetti in sviluppo e alla crescente domanda di soluzioni innovative per la transizione energetica.
title_it: 18 GW di progetti rinnovabili in connessione

title_en: Nedeljnik: Gazprom exits NIS ownership structure
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Shutterstock/BalkansCat) St. Petersburg-based Intelligence Joint Stock Company has acquired 11.3% of the shares of the Serbian Oil Industry (Naftna industrija Srbije - NIS) from energy giant Gazprom, thus crossing the threshold of a significant stake in one of the largest domestic companies. According to a document seen by the local weekly Nedeljnik, the transaction was completed on Friday, September 19, 2025. The “Notice of Significant Participation” signed by authorized representative Filip Bolgov states that the Russian company Intelligence acquired exactly 18,433,297 shares, representing an 11.3% stake in the company. Before this change, the company did not own any NIS shares, while the identical 11.3 percent of the capital was owned by Russia’s Gazprom. Gazprom is, by the way, a Russian state-owned company and one of the world’s largest producers and exporters of natural gas, while Gazprom Neft is its subsidiary in charge of crude oil operations. In the ownership structure of NIS, Gazprom Neft, the subsidiary of Gazprom in charge of crude oil operations, is currently the largest shareholder with 44.85%. The second largest shareholder is the state of Serbia with 29.87%, while Intelligence is now in third place with the aforementioned 11.3% of shares. The weekly states that the transaction was carried out based on the “Agreement on the Assignment/Transfer of Shares of a Joint Stock Company Without Compensation,” i.e. that the transfer of ownership was carried out free of charge. This ownership change is taking place at a time when NIS is requesting a postponement of the application of US sanctions for the seventh time. As the current license issued by the US Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) expires on September 26, NIS filed a new request on September 18 to continue to ensure uninterrupted operations. In parallel with these short-term measures, NIS is also waging a long-term legal battle, having sent an official request to be removed from the so-called SDN (Specially Designated Nationals) list on March 14. Previously, Srbijagas CEO Dusan Bajatovic reiterated that “there is a desire for Serbia to buy NIS, but the Russian side is currently not willing to sell the company.” Gazprom Moscow NIS a.d. content_it:
La società per azioni Intelligence con sede a San Pietroburgo ha acquisito l’11,3% delle azioni della Naftna Industrija Srbije (NIS) dal colosso energetico Gazprom, superando così la soglia di partecipazione significativa in una delle principali aziende serbe. Secondo un documento visionato dal settimanale serbo Nedeljnik, l’operazione si è conclusa venerdì 19 settembre 2025. La “Notifica di partecipazione significativa”, firmata dal rappresentante autorizzato Filip Bolgov, indica che la società russa Intelligence ha acquisito esattamente 18.433.297 azioni, pari all’11,3% del capitale sociale. Prima di questa operazione, Intelligence non deteneva alcuna quota in NIS, mentre la stessa percentuale era interamente in mano a Gazprom, società controllata dallo Stato russo e tra i maggiori produttori ed esportatori mondiali di gas naturale.  

Nell’attuale struttura azionaria di NIS, la controllata Gazprom Neft – responsabile delle attività nel settore del greggio – rimane azionista di maggioranza con il 44,85%. Al secondo posto figura lo Stato serbo con il 29,87%, seguito ora da Intelligence con l’11,3%. Il settimanale riferisce che la cessione è avvenuta tramite un “Accordo di cessione/trasferimento gratuito di azioni di società per azioni”, ossia senza corrispettivo economico.  

L’operazione si colloca in un momento delicato per NIS, che ha presentato il 18 settembre 2025 la settima richiesta di proroga dell’applicazione delle sanzioni statunitensi, in scadenza il 26 settembre. Parallelamente, l’azienda sta conducendo una battaglia legale di lungo termine e ha formalmente chiesto il 14 marzo scorso di essere rimossa dalla lista SDN (Specially Designated Nationals) del Dipartimento del Tesoro statunitense.  

In passato, il CEO di Srbijagas, Dušan Bajatović, aveva dichiarato che “esiste la volontà della Serbia di acquisire NIS, ma la controparte russa non è al momento disposta alla vendita”.  

Questa riorganizzazione azionaria potrebbe aprire future opportunità per operatori internazionali, comprese aziende italiane attive nel settore energetico, qualora la Serbia intensifichi gli sforzi per il riacquisto del controllo sull’azienda.
title_it: Gazprom cede quota NIS a Intelligence

title_en: Additional quantities gas to Serbia from Azerbaijan during winter – Signing of contract for construction of gas power plant in Nis also announced
content_en: Illustration (Photo: Shutterstock/fotokaleinar) Serbian Parliament President Ana Brnabic stated in Baku that Serbia would receive additional gas quantities from Azerbaijan during the winter months. – In addition to the already agreed gas quantities, at the explicit request of President (of Serbia Aleksandar) Vucic, Azerbaijan will meet the requirement to provide additional gas quantities for Serbia during the winter months. This will be very important for the upcoming winter – she told Serbian journalists after meetings with senior officials in Baku. She began her visit to Azerbaijan yesterday by laying wreaths at the tomb of national leader Heydar Aliyev in the Alley of Honor, as well as at the “Eternal Flame” monument in the Martyrs’ Lane. She met with President of the Azerbaijani Parliament Sahiba Gafarova, Prime Minister Ali Asadov, Minister of Finance and Co-Chair of the Intergovernmental Commission for Trade and Economic Cooperation between Serbia and Azerbaijan Sahil Babayev, as well as with Minister of Economy Mikayil Jabbarov. All of them, she stated, told her in their meetings that Serbia was a priority and that they would meet everything that its officials asked for. The contract for the construction of a gas power plant in Nis, which has already been agreed upon and is a joint investment of the two countries worth EUR 600 million, will be signed at the first meeting of the Strategic Cooperation Council, which will be held, as she said, when it suits the presidents of Serbia and Azerbaijan. – How important Azerbaijan is and how much it will be for energy, especially in Europe, is best demonstrated by the information that the Azerbaijani oil company SOCAR has bought the Italian oil company API for an incredible EUR 3 billion – she emphasized. – Today, energy security is an integral part of national security, and in that sense, Azerbaijan is one of our most important and loyal friends – she said, assessing yesterday’s visit as successful.
